<question>



Why do you like this job, Safeway?



explain in paragraph about this job or you have experience about this job..and tell me why do you this job? give me more details.



</question>



<answer from>



JC
Member since: 23 August 2006
Total points: 13800 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Ive been working for Safeway/Vons for 7 years. I work in the meat/seafood dept. I like what I do, but the grocery business is not like it used to be. I came in just in time but in recent years and contract negotiations, new employees do not get very much. Yeah, you can qualify for benefits which can make a big difference. But the company is not about taking care of you, regardless of the fact that it is a Fortune 500 multi billion dollar company. You still start out at just minimum wage as a courtesy clerk and have to pay Union dues, along with the initiation fee of about $200 (not to be paid all at once). They have what they call "World class service" meaning they have a program where the store gets mystery shopped on average twice a month and you get your own service scores. You have several attributes that you must do and if you miss just one, you missed the shop. You have to greet every customer (whether they are looking at you or not), you must anticipate, meaning you have to ask if they need help, you have to offer to take to an item (you cannot just say "its on aisle 10" and leave it at that). You also must give a parting comment. You cannot just say 'thank you' but you must add something like 'have a nice day'. As a courtesy clerk, you have to offer to take them to their car and thank them by name (this is supposed to be helped out by the checker who sees the customers name on a check or credit card but is not always followed through).  Its all about having to do some serious as* kissing to every customer since you have no idea where or when a mystery shopper rolls in.



Much easier to get a job at McDonalds.



Good luck.



</answer>

<question>



How would you sell a bachelors degree if you only have an associates?



I'm interviewing for a position which requires me to sell bachelors and even masters degrees. A question on my interview will be how do i sell to students these higher education degrees, while I've only been able to complete my associates. any ideas? thanks!



</question>



<answer from>



Flyby
Member since: 23 November 2006
Total points: 3792 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I don't see that your personal education should be a factor when looking at selling to students. I would concentrate on how the higher degrees will benefit the students. Focus your attention on the student and benefits of having a higher degree. Some careers only need an associates degree. Most companies look to those with bachelors or masters degrees when they look for those for advancement. In your situation, you can always get a BS. If nothing else it could help your confidence level when talking with these people.



</answer>

<answer>



I think this is nature's test for her to see how badly she wants to be qualified for her job, and how much she really wants to do this.



Right now she's focused on the short-term inconvenience, which of course is very easy to do - since that is what is directly effecting her life right now.



But I think she needs to take some serious time (like at least 3 weeks) to think about this long-term.  I think it'd be worse for her to drop out and then regret it on down the road, and one day say (say 5 years down the road), "Oh I was SO close, I should've finished."



A year is not forever.  It's not long at all.  I went on vacation in September 2007 across country and I can't BELIEVE it's been that long.  It doesn't seem like a year whatsoever.



Like I said, I think she needs to fairly weigh both the short-term and long-term pros and cons.  She's already been dwelling on the short-term.  She needs to take a few weeks to focus on what she wants for herself in the future.



(My two cents:  It would not be worth it for her to invest this much time and effort, only to quit now... esp. not with the economy as it is.)

<answer>



I have always been a firm believer that our job should be our avocation. In other words I think we should find a job that we can enjoy. After all, we will spend at least 1/3 of our life doing it. On the other hand I don't know your friend or what she enjoys. No one but your friend can decide what is best for her. Since she is having such a difficult time making a decision I will suggest something that might help. Tell her to get a piece of paper and draw a line down the middle. On one side write the pros of staying where she is. On the other side write the cons of staying. Write down everything you can think of in each column. The column with the most reasons makes your decision. You can use this method for any major decision you need to make if you have difficulty deciding what you need to do.

<answer from>



Flyby
Member since: 23 November 2006
Total points: 3792 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



A cover letter is simply a way to briefly introduce yourself to a prospective employer. You summarize your experience and how that may be of value to the employer. You don't need to write a book. All you want is to get an interview. It should not be any longer than 3 paragraphs. Approach it much the same way you would when doing an outline for a paper. Sentences should be short and concise. You need to address the position for which you are applying, your experience and education as it relates to the position. You need to express your interest and ask for an interview. The cover letter should not sound arrogant nor should it sound desperate. State your qualifications, interest in the position and why it would be to the benefit of the company for them to hire you.



</answer>



<answer from>



mark m
Member since: 04 September 2007
Total points: 5637 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Writing application letter:
There are some general rules you should follow when applying for a job and writing application letter, if you follow them you may find yourself in a new job sooner than you think:



1- Research and investigation: try to read between the lines and get a feeling about the person who wrote the ad and the company way of thinking.
2- Language and style: your letter serve only one purpose: to get you invited for a job interview, hence, avoid hackneyed phrases and cliches. you language should be alive and vivid and should attract the reader's attention, spelling mistakes and grammatical or syntax errors and cardinal sins and will almost certainly cause your application to end up in the rubbish bin.
3- Presentation: Give your application a nice look, use only top quality paper, print it out on a laser printer or good quality inkjet, be conservative with colours, when you mail it don't fold it or staple it.
4- Follow up: when you send your job application to a prospective employer, make a note in your diary and keep photocopies of all correspondence, after a week or so, telephone the employer just to confirm that they received your application.
5- The method: there are few basic methods you can use to get your application into the hand of a prospective employer,, E-mail, Fax or by normal mail.
Remember, applying foe a job is like a seduction. Would you fax a love poem to your sweetheart, or would you present it in person? so I suggest to take it by hand, if delivering you application in person is not practical or would be too expensive, consider using a courier service.
All the best, I hope you get the job.



Source(s):



</answer>

<question>



Do states require permission for an employer to run a background check on a minor?



If someone is seventeen does the company have to gain permission? Sixteen? This is if the person already works for the company. The state (if it matters) is Kansas



</question>



<additional details>



What if the employer runs one after the employee is already hired(like months later). Do they need permision because they are 16?



</additional details>



<answer from>



michr
Member since: 03 February 2007
Total points: 52550 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Health Care



Law & Legal



Other - Careers & Employment



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



ALL background checks are covered by federal law,



the "Fair Credit Reporting Act".
the information contained in a background check is gathered by using public information.



a release must be signed for the check to be done and a minor may sign the release, a parent or guardians signature is not required.
however..........very limited information is obtainable for minors.
a release is required for pre-employment or for a current employee.



Federal Trade Commission
Fair Credit Reporting Act
http://www.ftc.gov/os/statutes/031224fcr...



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks for the website!



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



jobbend
Member since: 23 March 2008
Total points: 2819 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



In general, an employer must gain your consent to do a background check. This can be done a number of ways - including having you sign an application that gives them the right to do a check.  I looked at the KS state site and I did not find anything that spoke directly to this.  However, the state of KS has very liberal laws regarding the availability of background information to most anyone.  I'd check with the KS Department of Labor for the specific answer.



</answer>

<answer>



You are more attractive to potential employers if you are working so beware.  And if you have little to do, you should have time to plan your strategy and think about your next move.



But better still, consider if there are ways to make your existing employment more productive.  You are lucky to have a job!



What about looking for things to do like sorting old files?  That storage room?  You could label and reorganise that.  People aren't going to suggest these things but you can find them for yourself.



Or what about taking evening classes to learn something new, perhaps something that will help you improve your position where you are working?  A new skill or a higher qualification.  It is always easier to upgrade with the firm you are with than to convince a new employer that you are worth taking a risk over.  And a job that demands little from you is an ideal place to be when you are studying as it will be less tiring.



Look at the big picture and take advantage of what you have!

<category>

Careers & Employment



</category>



<question from>



nhxj4x4
Member since: 21 September 2007
Total points: 197 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Employer says they will not hire a relative. Is that legal?



My brother-in-law would like to apply for the same company that I work for. He's situation is unique as he is military and would have to interview in a place other than which he wishes to relocate to. That being said I asked the question as I posted above and through the chain of e-mails I was then told by HR that we are not longer hiring relatives. Now I feel that I have inadvertently gotten him black listed as even if he applies now they will know who he is. Is this legal? Is this discriminatory?



</question>



<answer from>



Books
Member since: 10 August 2008
Total points: 1856 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



This is a common situation for many businesses.  Having relatives working together can cause problems, petty jealousies, and feelings of favoritism.  They prevent all this by not hiring relatives.  Being a relative is not a protected class, so it's legal and not discrimination.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks, not the answer I hoped for as I still find it unfair, but it is what it is.



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Judy
Member since: 14 February 2006
Total points: 181895 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Law & Legal



United States



</answer from>



<answer>



Absolutely legal.  And I don't think you fully understand "discriminatory".  Discrimination, in the legal sense, is treating someone differently because of something prohibited by law, like their gender, race, religion or national origin.  There is no law about hiring or not hiring relatives of current employees.



</answer>

<answer from>



minette n
Member since: 05 July 2006
Total points: 176 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



You need to be in the RN Program of an accredited school, either community or private. Of course with the community college, you pay less money but more time consuming and patience since it's full time. If you go to a private school, you get weekend studies as short as 18 months but you have to pay more, about $20,000-25,000 for the whole course. After graduating and passing the RN board exam you need to be employed in an acute hospital in their Medical-Surgical floor (MEd-Surg for short) for a year or two before you can be transferred to their specialized floors which are the following: OB, Cardiac Step-down, Ambulatory Care Unit, ER, ICU, etc. There are instances that if you know somebody inside the company, he/she can help you go through the specialty areas faster. Remember, an RN is a 2-year course. A BSN is a 4-year course. Either an RN or BSN can work in the same hospital. Any college that is accredited by the Board of Education is fine. The most important thing to remember is YOU NEED TO PASS THE BOARD EXAM! With an RN degree, you can pretty much work in any hospital and any nursing field you want. With the BSN, it's more of administration and advance managerial positions. With RNs, it's possible also to be the director of nurses in a convalescent or home health companies if you have enough experience in managing staff nurses. I suggest you start as an RN and walk your way up. The lower you start, the more you understand the profession and your accountability and responsibility to the people who are in need of your care.



Source(s):



My experience.



</answer>

Which is a more difficult profession: Nurse Anesthetist or Physician's Assistant?

<answer from>



Diane A
Member since: 26 April 2007

Health Care

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



CRNA training is very extensive, but once you graduate you are in a pretty narrow setting which is very controlled i.e. monitors, drugs at hand, etc (the OR or similar, giving anesthesia)--while this can be harrowing at times, you are well trained.  Depending on their practice; a PA can be responsible for taking care of and diagnosing a hundred different patients a day with no idea what's going on, doing minor surgery, running code blues etc.  In my book, that can really be scary as well. </answer from>



<answer>



In general, the comp time must equal 1 1/2 times the overtime worked.  For example, if the 14 hours you listed was how much your friend worked, your company must give her 21 hours of comp time.



The Office of Wage and Hour at the US Department of Labor is the agency that oversees pay and overtime.  Check at http://www.dol.gov/esa for more info.



Source(s):



http://www.nolo.com/article.cfm/objectId...



</answer>



<answer from>



One Step Ahead
Member since: 05 September 2008
Total points: 556 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



All over time has to be pre-approved by your supervisor. Who authorized her to work these extra hours??



Some companies have a policy that they do not pay $$ for overtime, but they give compensation time off. The benefits have to be based on time and a half off from work.  If she actually worked  10 hours of overtime, then the comp time would be 15 hours off.



Again, it is up to the company went she can use this time. Most companies want you to use the time before the year is over.



I had overtime accurate one time that I took four Fridays off in a row.  The company was low on funds, and the business was beginning to pick up again. We were told in advance  that we would not be paid money, but time off at the same rate(time and a half).



</answer>

<question from>



tesslock...
Member since: 20 January 2008
Total points: 180 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Medical sign/ logo? Juz curious..?



why is it that when i see a medical building, the sign is a pin w/ or w/o wings and one or two snakes around it? What does it symbolize or mean? what does each figure mean ( snake, pin, wings)? what about all together.



If you can answer this it would be helpful to me. tnx. :)



</question>



<answer from>



Texas
Member since: 01 November 2008
Total points: 318 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



There are 2 different symbols with different meanings dating back to the ancient Greeks.



The rod of Asclepius symbolizes the healing arts by combining the serpent, which in shedding its skin is a symbol of rebirth and fertility, with the staff, a symbol of authority befitting the god of Medicine.



The rod of Asclepius has one snake coiled around a rod.



The rod of Caduceus is more ornate and has 2 snakes coiled around a rod topped with wings.  This more ornate rod is associated with Hermes the messenger, and has association with Trade and Communications.



Sometimes some in and around the Medical community may have mistaken the 2 symbols, and inappropriately use the one with 2 snakes and wings as a Medical symbol, when this is not its original intended meaning.



Source(s):



http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rod_of_Ascl...
http://www.aglp.org/gap/8_ethics/Asclepi...
http://medgadget.com/archives/2005/06/th...



</answer>



<asker's comment>



tnx



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



Sincere Questioner
Member since: 04 August 2006
Total points: 4153 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



It is called a "caduceus," or a "winged caduceus."



It is a sign of the god Hermes (Mercury), who is the patron of, and revealer of the hidden (hermetic) sciences. These sciences are for the benefit of all and include the healing arts. This is why they are used as a symbol for medicine.



Another alternate provenance is from the book of Numbers in the bible (chapter 21, verse 8). Here it says to set up an image of a serpent on a pole. Anyone who looks at this serpent on a pole would be spared from the deadly snake bites that were afflicting the Israelites in their journey through the wilderness.



Source(s):



Hermes Trismegistus



</answer>



<answer from>



Diane A
Member since: 26 April 2007
Total points: 24086 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Health Care



</answer from>



<answer>



Texas has it correct.  The Two-winged staff is incorrect (and is the symbol of winged Apollo--when you see him he has wings on his feet & carries the staff); and the wooden staff with the single serpent is correct.  It is the symbol of Aesculapius; a very famous Greek physician who was deified.  His daughters were Hygiea (hygiene) and Panacea (also means a cure for all).  His temple is in the Tiber River and it was felt that leaving someone overnight in it would cure them (and snakes lived in the temple as they could not get off the island). You can google both Apollo & Aesculapius for much more info--its pretty interesting.



Source(s):



ER PA/MD



</answer>

</answer>

<question>



3 month notice period on current contract.?



have found a new job, signed a contract but I have a 3 month notice period on my current contract. I only want to do 1 month but my employers are insisting I do 3. What can they do if I say no but give them 1 months notice in writing? Can they sue me for breach of contract. Are they likely to?



</question>



<additional details>



I am in London so UK laws apply.



</additional details>



<answer from>



Flyby
Member since: 23 November 2006
Total points: 3826 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



You can be held accountable for any agreement you signed. You should contact the new employer and tell them the circumstances and your agreement with your current employer. They may be willing to wait until you can fulfill your agreement. You should never sign an agreement that you are unwilling to fulfill. They could sue you and possibly your new employer as well if you fail to honor your contract with them.



</answer>



<answer from>



Original...
Member since: 05 July 2006
Total points: 14015 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



TBH it depends on what you do, if you do a more low paid job they are not likely to sue, but you wont get your last months salary.



If you are on a higher salary they might well sue



</answer>



<answer from>



Cari
Member since: 01 October 2006
Total points: 21064 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Other - Careers & Employment



Renting & Real Estate



</answer from>



<answer>



Yes, they can sue you.  But all they can really sue you for is any costs that you have forced them to incur.  So, for example, if they were to hire a temp to do your job, then they could sue you for the cost of this (and that would be more than your salary, once agency costs are added in).



Would they sue you?  Well, probably not ... if you think about how much their legal expenses would be if they tried to sue you, and how much effort it would be, then it really wouldn't be worth it.



However, it largely depends on which company you're leaving your employer for.  If it's a close competitor, it's likely that they don't want you joining this company while you have so much intellectual property related to them and the industry.  So if this were the case then they'd be more likely to sue you.



Aside from being sued, you also want to think about:
- References - it's likely that they will tell any future employer that you breached your contractual notice period
- Burning bridges - you don't know when you're going to need people in the future.  You may not have any intention of ever returning to that company, but you don't know when you are going to run in certain individuals again



</answer>

<question from>

<question>



Offer Letter for a job Question?



You will also receive relocation assistance for the moving of your Household Goods (exception of vehicles).



In accepting the relocation assistance you agree to work for our company for a minimum of 1 year or reimburse our company on a 12 month prorated basis.
What exactly does Prorated basis mean???



</question>



<answer from>



Kris L
Member since: 22 December 2006
Total points: 55294 (Level 7)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



That means that if you work for the company only 5 months, you'd need to pay them 7/12ths of the cost of the move.  If you work for them for 10 months, you'd pay them for 2/12ths of the move.  That is what 'prorated basis' means.



</answer>

Thanks for the help, that's what I thought but I just wanted to make sure.



</asker's comment>

<question from>



Leslie C
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 95 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Do criminal background checks show everything you've ever been charged with?



or just everything you've been found guilty of or convicted of.



</question>



<answer from>



Eddy
Member since: 24 September 2008
Total points: 270 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



The information included in a criminal record varies between countries and even between jurisdictions within a country. In most cases it lists all non-expunged criminal offenses and may also include traffic offenses such as speeding and drunk-driving. In some countries the record is limited to actual convictions (where the individual has pleaded guilty or been proven guilty in court of law), while in others it also includes arrests, charges dismissed, charges pending, and even charges of which the subject has been acquitted. The latter policy is often argued to be a human rights violation, since it works against the presumption of innocence (in the sense that it exposes people against whom there is no positive proof of guilt to possible discrimination for their alleged crimes).



Source(s):



http://www.wikipedia.com



</answer>



<answer from>



Flyby
Member since: 23 November 2006
Total points: 3826 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



It will likely show anything that you were charged with even if there was no conviction. Some states allow for expunging of offenses where charges were dropped or found not guilty.



</answer>



<answer from>



Cubs Girl
Member since: 10 October 2008
Total points: 1140 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



It shows everything.....Company's can only go with items that have been charge or convicted and can go back only 7 years.



</answer>

Politica...

<answer>



Why not take this one step at a time?



If you do not have an undergraduate degree, get one at night school.  That way you don't run up any debts.



Having done that, take a hard look at what Masters programmes that are attractive to you would get you a better job and do the maths before you enroll.



Then you will know whether taking a Masters as well makes sense.  It does not always.

<answer from>



Henry
Member since: 28 March 2008
Total points: 3283 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



See if your current employer offer tuition reimbursement.  If they do you can go back to school on their dime.  Once they are done paying for your education, you can go find another job that you will enjoy more than your current one.



If your current employer doesn't offer any tuition reimbursement, then you'll have a tough decision to make.  You can either quit your job and apply for financial aid to pay for your education.  Or, you can stick it out with your current employer and make the best of a bad situation and maybe take some night classes on your own dime.



As an aside:  Whatever reason(s) it is you're unhappy with your current employer, you should try to find a way to make it better.  Talk to your boss to see if there's something else you could within the organization that will give you more job satisfaction.  You're getting paid pretty generously for a secretary, I wouldn't just throw that away.  It generally boils down to what will make you happier and what career you feel will be more gratifying.



Hope this helps or at least leads you in the right direction.



</answer>

<answer from>



michr
Member since: 03 February 2007
Total points: 52564 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Health Care



Law & Legal



Other - Careers & Employment



</answer from>



<answer>



go to most any nursing home and they will train you and pay for the state test to become a CNA.



it takes 75 hours to become certified, 40 hours classroom and 35 hours of clinical work and in Missouri an additional 100 hours of "on-the-job" experience. once you are certified and working you will find many homes will reimburse or pay for your continuing education in nursing.
being a CNA is EXTREMELY hard and often underpaid work but there is no more important and/or rewarding job that can be done.
for info:
http://www.bls.gov/oco/ocos165.htm
http://www.dhss.mo.gov/CNARegistry/FAQs....
http://www.dhss.mo.gov/NursingHomes/Cert...



</answer>



<answer from>



mtwaites
Member since: 02 September 2008
Total points: 5729 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



CNA can be a very hard job, but it will give you some experience, and some headway before you gain experience into become a Registered Nurse. Many areas will allow you to bridge into the RN program if you are a nursing assistant and then have had experience.



</answer>

<question>



Medical Secretary Position- What should I add besides a resume and cover letter?



I've applied online for a secretarial job at one of our local hospitals.  I really want the position so I have decided to also send a resume and cover letter to the human resources office.  What other things can I add to make myself stand out above the crowd?  Any answers are appreciated.  Thanks and have a wonderful day! : )



</question>



<answer from>



gettingb...
Member since: 03 February 2008
Total points: 5511 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Make sure your cover letter is PERFECT. No errors at all. Have someone proof it for you-I always do, because a second set of eyes is great. Make sure you put the name of the hospital on the letter, so it is personalized. If you do not have a name to send the letter to, write:



Dear Hiring Manager:



Your resume needs to be updated and perfect, too. Did you go to school for this? If so, add a copy of your diploma/cert. to the resume and cover letter.



After you send it, wait a few days, call and see if it was received. That is about all you can do at this point.



GOOD LUCK!



</answer>

<answer>



I've had this happen to me on 2 separate jobs. As you walk through the office, take a look at the other employees' faces. Do they look happy? If you get introduced to someone who works below the manager/director who's interviewing you, ask her questions like how long she's been with the company, etc. Don't ask her directly about her relationship with her upper, but keep a close ear on whether she has any praise for her.

<answer from>



Steve H
Member since: 03 November 2008
Total points: 112 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



You have the right not to be bullied or harassed in the work place. That happens in High School and below.



I think you need to keep looking until you find that particular job which "fits" you. Everyone fits in somewhere. You just haven't found your niche yet. Obviously, the place you worked at last is not for you. It's only a job. I would just take the experience of it in stride. I wouldn't give it another thought.



It is normal for people to change their jobs often until they find what they like doing in a comfortable job environment. That's how you learn what you like and don't like in a job.



You may want to take a few "personality and career" assessment tests and see where they "suggest" you fit in the job world. They inventory all your skills, aptitudes and interests. It's worthwhile.



I would try doing this first. You may come up with career choices that you haven't thought of. You may be pleased with the various career choices suggested to you. There are "free" tests online. Just type in free career or free personality tests in your browser's search window.
I hope this helps. Good luck.



Source(s):



http://www.career-test-info-guide.com



</answer>

<question from>



Chasity C
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 91 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



How much more education would i need to get to RN if i am already CMA w/ Radiology Certified?



What is the next level up from MA?  I know not LPN because they are on the same level.



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Unfortunately, you still need to start at the bottom of the education.  Your next level would be an RN and that would be either an associates degree (ADN) from a community college or a bachelors (BSRN) from a university.  Depending on your previous education, you may get some credit for some of the pre-reqs but you will not get any credit for the core nursing classes.  Your best bet would be to get your transcripts and have them evaluated at whatever place you are trying for the RN.  Taking Xrays is not part of the RN curricula anyway, so that will not gain you anything in the nursing program. But if you took any gen ed classes etc that might get you a few classes (or more) shaved off the gen classes in the program.



Source(s):



ER PA



</answer>

<answer from>



minette n
Member since: 05 July 2006
Total points: 186 (Level 1)

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



If you're in California there is an Emergency Medi-Cal available to both young and adult. However, for 18years old and below, the state offers a full coverage Medi-Cal for children, including hospitalizations, well check ups and immunizations as long as the child qualifies for the low income family bracket, and a US citizen.

Medi-Cal

<answer>

<answer from>



Meghan
Member since: 30 May 2007
Total points: 8797 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



For starters, it takes time to get calls back.  I'd consider going to a recruiter or temp agency and get your foot in the door with companies that way.



It also sounds like your resume is just too long and not to the point.  Forget the long 2 pages, and skip the "buzz words".  Try to highlight your accomplishments at each position, and what set you apart from your coworkers.  Focus on the skills you have, not how many "buzz words" you can put on piece of paper.  An employer can see right through that crap.



</answer>

<question>



How much do legal assistants earn per year?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



There is no specific answer. It depends on who you work for, and where you work-actual town or city. Larger areas and firms tend to pay more than smaller ones.



Also, "legal assistant" can mean different duties. If you are handling the duties of a paralegal, you will be paid more than if you are doing less complex duties. Some firms use this title for paralegals, while other firms use it as a title for clerical/administrative assistants. It depends on what the firm requires of you.



I have seen paralegal salaries ranging from 30K-80K, and I had an interview for a legal assistant that was paying $10/per hour, because it was handling clerical duties, phones, etc. and helping the paralegals. It had none of the paralegal duties. However, I just saw an ad for a legal assistant that was actually a paralegal job, and it was paying 50K. So, it really varies.



</answer>

<question from>



prava
Member since: 17 May 2006
Total points: 175 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Nursing ques- whats the diff bet Nurse, Rn, Lpn- in terms of education (yrs), salary- and how high up u can go?



plus, what schools in NY/NYC would you recommend?



</question>



<answer from>



Amanda C
Member since: 27 April 2008
Total points: 816 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



RN makes substantially more than a LPN. Takes longer to be an RN. and there are alot of limitless oppurtunities in the nursing field.  RN have alot more responsibility than an LPN. LPN typically work in an nursing home as RN can work anywhere Hospitals, DR Offices and etc..



I dont live in NYC so I cannot reccommend any schools do a little research and find some. Look for  accredidation, able to transfer credits and so forth. good luck!



Source(s):



going to school to be an LPN then an RN



</answer>



<answer from>



Jill
Member since: 05 May 2007
Total points: 64178 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Health Care



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



You can become an LPN in about 9-12 months. While some schools offer an Associates Degree LPN program, most of the time you are not earning a degree. You will earn about $14-20 per hour to start, some places might pay a bit more, but almost definitely not more than $25 per hour even with years of experience.



You can be an RN with as little as an Associate's Degree, which is a two-year program, however there are pre-requisite courses in biology, chemistry, etc. which must be completed before you start the nursing courses, so most people end up taking about 3 years to complete the degree.



You can become an LPN first, then take a RN bridge program, which usually takes about another 12-18 months.



Or, you could go straight for your BSN / BAN, a full four year degree in nursing. While both the Associates and the BSN allow you to take your RN licensure exam (same test for either degree option), you are provided with a more well rounded education, and trained in more of a leadership capacity with the BSN / BAN degree, therefore in the long run you will be more eligible for promotions and positions beyond regular bedside staff nursing. If you do the Assoc. program first, you can complete the BSN / BAN later, and most employers offer some kind of tuition reimbursement these days.



In a regular staff nurse position, you will make anywhere from $25-$35 per hour to start, if you hold the BSN degree it might pay about a dollar more per hour. The pay differences with the higher degree only start to kick in if you are in other positions, like supervisory or management. In those positions, you can make $60k per year and up to start.



You can go on to specialize and earn a Master's Degree where you could focus on being a Nurse Practitioner, Clinical Nurse Specialist, Certified Nurse Midwife, Certified Registered Anesthetist, Nurse Educator, etc. You could then go on and earn your Doctorate in nursing and work in research or higher education or other high level administration positions.



Opportunities are endless as far as education and specialty areas.



</answer>

<question>



Which is the highest earning speciality of doctors?



i want to know which type of doctor(eg. Neurosurgeon, Pediatrician) earns the highest amount of money



</question>



<answer from>



minette n
Member since: 05 July 2006
Total points: 237 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



The highest earner depends on how many patients and what kind of insurance you accept. If you have many patients but then 50% are on Medicaid or Medicare, then you're not earning much. However, the specialists actually earn more than the Internal Medicine, Pediatrics and Family Practice doctors because they are the primary doctors who get those patients on Medicaid or Medicare. The specialists tend to accept more private/commercial insurances.  I read from an article sometime ago that the best paying ones are in the Ortho Sports Medicine. Why, well, many, especially kids, gets simple  injuries to major bone fractures or displacements that need major procedures and/or prostheses. I used to work in a peds office and almost every 2-3 days, we had a patient with a fracture because of merely playing in the school grounds. These kids are send by the primary doctors to the orthopedics for further evaluation and intervention. How about injuries in the workplace? Professional football players and the likes? Neurosurgeons or Heart surgeons maybe one of the highest paying but to compare the number of cases they handle, I believe Ortho Sport Medicine has more.



</answer>

<answer from>



almcneil...
Member since: 07 March 2006
Total points: 2660 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Although you never signed a non-disclosure agreement, that doesn't mean you aren't legally under that agreement. There are laws that protect business in the absence of a written agreement.



Although I am not an employment lawyer, I think it's well within the right of an employer to ask who you are going to. At the same time, you do not have to disclose it but that would make them assume it's a competitor. It's then the employers decision to allow you to work through your notice period or pay you a layoff and walk you out the door. Note; if it's the latter, it doesn't have to be equal to your notice period.



I would have in my resignation without stating who I'm going to. But, naturally, they will ask. Then I would state who it is and see how they react. Worst case, they pay you out and walk you out the door. Oh well. that's the capitalist economy we live in!



-- Liam



</answer>

<answer>



Do you ask them what their problems are and then explain how you would solve stuff?  That is the best way to win a job.  Extend yourself beyond just interviewing and move to the mode of consultant. I am a manager and I can talk all day long about my problems but nobody cares.  I sure wish I could find people who wanted to focus on my concerns by asking questions and then telling me how they can fix my problems.

<category>



Business & Finance

</category>



<question from>



SaMaNthA...
Member since: 22 August 2007
Total points: 119 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



I have a job interview as a receptionist @ a doctor's office on Thurs. and i need help!!!?



I've been to a few interviews but they don't call me back so I need this job but I don't know if to tell them i quit my last job( i had some problems like show up late b/c I was going through some things)but now i want a fresh new start.Should I leave my last job out of my resume b/c I don't want them giving bad references .I need advise please. Oh and I dont have any experience working in a doctor's office but I have all the skills to do it and learn so how can I say all that @ the interview.



</question>



<answer from>



ramshead...
Member since: 07 May 2006
Total points: 266 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



If you can leave it off without resulting in a huge time gap in your career track, then I would do it.  But if you were there for quite a while, then the time between your previous job and the present could invite questions about the gap.  You will need to have an answer to a question about what you have been doing in the meantime.  If you think it will be too difficult to conceal, then I would put it on the resume, but be prepared to discuss why you left.  The description you gave in your question is a terrible answer.  I would say something like, "I had some personal challenges that consumed a lot of my time and I thought it was unfair to my employer until I solved my issues.  Those problems are now all resolved and I'm ready to contribute as I know I can."  Not having experience in a doc's office puts you behind someone who does, but you still got an interview.  There's a good chance that you competition for the job doesn't have the experience either.  If they had a lot of experienced applicants, then you wouldn't have gotten an interview.  Ask about the essential requirements of the job and give specific examples from your past of how you have met those requirements.  You need to answer questions by citing past examples of your experience.  Claiming to be a good learner is not nearly as good as reciting your past success at picking up new tasks.  Give concrete examples.  Good luck!



</answer>

<answer>



Hi,
As already said, don't include things that may go against you but be ready with an answer if they notice there are gaps in your employment record.



Dress business like, prepare some answers of questions that are likely to come up, for example why do you want the job? Don't say because you need it, say positive things like because you have organisation skills and are good with people and you want to apply those to do a good job there (assuming all that is true). Another question might be what can you bring to the job? Detail the skills you have that are relevant and yes by all means say that the specific requirements of the job you are keen to learn.



Good luck,
Bill

<question>



Getting Promoted in The Fast Food Industry?



Ok so, I work for a KFC franchise in Minnesota, but I kinda have a problem.
I'm a shift manager at the store I work at, and I might just be putting not as much faith in myself as i should but heres the situation.
Hourly pay ranges for 6.75 -about 8.00 (Team Members- Shift mangers)
And the Salary Management positions range 25k per year - 50k + depending on store and labor/ food costs (assistant mangersGM's)



All the stores in the district are pretty close like all the GM's talk to each other alot so word gets to our district manager fairly easy.



I recently talked to our district manager about advancing to Salaried assistant manger job, expressing that i would like to go to more of the meetings, and employee improvement and training classes.
In his eyes he talks highly of me to the GM's in the district and all the GM's i know speek highly of me as far as work effort, experience and skills.
I'm just worried because our company is so big that other people most less qualified than me being able to move into that position, because people will gladly drive farther or move for such a big pay increase.
I'm just wondering if anyone has any tips about types of things i can do to secure that im a top choice of being promoted.
The DM told my boss to train me on the things i will need to learn in this new position, but sometimes the followthrough on his end can be scattered.
Tips anyone?



</question>



<answer from>



sphinxte...
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 148 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



do the math, as a manager making $25000 a year you will be taking a pay cut. salaried managers work 55 hrs a week, and at $25K thats $480 before taxes a week. $8 an hour for 55 hrs is $500 a week before taxes (40 hrs X $8 + 15 hrs X $12 overtime pay). I worked as a manager and NEVER worked the 55 hrs, it was always about 62 hrs plus there was homework. I had no life. here's my tip for you, get a job at a sit down restaurant as a bus person, tell them you would like to learn to be a server. bus people make around $75 a day cash tips plus $3.08 an hour. servers make $3.08 an hour and anywhere from $75 to $300 a day, I average $180 a day and work only 4 days a week! I now have a great life and my managers are working 50 hours a week. non-chain restaurants start managers off at $35,000 a year and work less than chain managers, I have seen 2 servers get promoted to manager this year and they are doing well. my GM makes $95,000 a year and I have another from another location who is 28 years old and is the GM, who started as a backwaiter! get out of fast food, it's a nowhere job, good luck!



</answer>

<question>



Applying for a job, what does this mean?



"Will you now or in the future require sponsorship for an employment visa (for example, H-1B visa)?"



idk if i should put yes or no because i dont understand what it is.



</question>



<answer from>



scrapboo...
Member since: 26 October 2008
Total points: 664 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



If you are a US citizen, the answer is NO



People who are here from other counties need a special visa if they are not citizens and want to work here.



</answer>



<answer from>



Brian T
Member since: 30 October 2008
Total points: 238 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



That means if your employer will need to sponsor you if you are a foreign national working in the US. They want to know if you can work in the US without their sponsorship.



My roommate was from France and had that exact visa. He was working for BT in New York and could stay as long as he worked for them. Once he quit it was right back to France with him.



If you're an American citizen put no. if you're not a legal resident put yes. The longest you can stay in the us with out a work visa is 90 days, so you would need your company to sponsor you.



</answer>



<answer from>



TheSimpl...
Member since: 29 April 2006
Total points: 9467 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



They're asking you if you need a work visa sponsorship. Some employers will sponsor someone that does not live in the country their business is in.



If you are a citizen of that country, check no.



If you are an immigrant or do not live in the country the company is in, check yes. :)



</answer>

</answer from>



<answer>



I worked in a movie theater for two years



As a girl you work at the concession stand, giving people popcorn and soda and all the other goodies, as well as you make the popcorn and the nachos, etc. throughout the day



Or you work at the box office printing the tickets and giving them out to people. Usually the guys are the ones that clean, but the positions can tend to switch around depending on the place that you work at

since you're young you'll get along great seeing as you'll be working with a lot of other young folks

<question>



Two weeks notice or longer?



i plan on leaving my job by dec. 18th.



they treated me very well, so i am concerned as to my replacement because they will be in training for two weeks and of course the time that it takes to hire somebody new will take a while



should i wait to give my notice two weeks before that, or sooner?



(i work in a small deli)



</question>



<additional details>



how soon should i give it?



would i be jumping the gun to give my letter of resitnation immediately?



</additional details>



<answer from>



ronald h
Member since: 25 April 2007
Total points: 435 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Depends on your relationship with the owner or manager. You are only obligated to give two weeks. Since they treated you well they probably would appreciate you giving as much notice as possible.  Discuss your leaving with them before handing them the resignation letter. Point out you would be happy to help train your replacement. Also ask them if they would give you a written recommendation. The worst you would hear is no.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thanks, i think i'll wait a little longer, but probably probably give about 3 weeks :)



</asker's comment>



<answer from>



almcneil...
Member since: 07 March 2006
Total points: 2660 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



There is no labour that states you must give notice of resignation. There is what is called "professional courtesy" and it stipulates that you should give adequate notice commensurate with your seniority and length of service. It's enough noticed that the employer can make arrangements to handover responsibilities to someone else and start a job search for yoru replacement. So if you worked there less than two years and in a non-management role, 2 weeks is fine. If you are a manager and worked there 5 years, then 3 or 4 weeks.



-- Liam



</answer>



<answer from>



A E
Member since: 10 October 2008
Total points: 588 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Since you already know you should probably give notice early. It will give them more time to find your replacement. You can either write them a letter and say why you are going to leave or talk to someone in person but I'm pretty sure they will want it in writing. Also you never know if you will run into your old boss somewhere or if you ever need a reference or a job. It's better to build bridges and not burn them.



Source(s):



personal experience



</answer>

<question>



I applied for a job on 9/29 and the job closed the next day, I havent heard from them.  Should I call?



The job is for a recreational therapist job at a nearby airforce base and I have not heard anything in regards of the job position.  Should I give them a call now, wait, or don't call at all?



thanks!



</question>



<answer from>



gettingb...
Member since: 03 February 2008
Total points: 5551 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Is it an actual federal job or a job through a private contractor? If it is a federal job, it can take a while for them to call. There is a process to it, and it can take weeks for them to contact you. You SHOULD get a notice in the mail or by email, saying that they have hired someone else, or you did not make it to the interview process. I have applied for several federal jobs, and it took about a month for them to send an email saying they had chosen someone else.



If it is a private contractor, then you probably should have heard by now, but I have had a couple places call several months after I applied. Sometimes, they take a LONG time to fill the jobs.



You can call, but check the listing and see if they say no calls. Sometimes they do, and in that case, I would leave it be.



Good luck!



</answer>

<answer from>



maxmom56
Member since: 25 February 2008
Total points: 14511 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Wait until the criminal trial is over.  You may be able to sue and get a judgment fairly easily is the guy is convicted since the criminal standard of proof is higher than the civil.  While the judgment may not be collectible, it will be valid for a long time (in NY, 10 years and renewable for another 10) and accrues interest.  You never know what's going to happen in the future.  A judgment may be a handy thing to have in your back pocket.



Source(s):



20+ years practicing law



</answer>



<answer from>



Mali
Member since: 02 October 2008
Total points: 126 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



The laws vary from state to state so your best bet would be to call an attorney in your local area. Most reputable attorneys will discuss this matter with you free of charge.



You are correct though, if this person is 19 years old and obviously nowhere near an outstanding citizen your chances of getting anything in a civil trial would be slim to none. You'd end up spending more in attorney fees than you'd ever see from him especially since it sounds like he'll be in prison for a long time.  There is some good news though.  Depending on the state you live in part of his punishment in the criminal trial may be some sort of monetary reimbursement (restitution) to the victim. That is something you may want to bring up to the prosecutor.



</answer>

<answer>



The min. salary is twice the states minimum wage times 40 hours a week. That means you would have to make an hourly wage that is double the minimum wage and you would have to be paid for at least 40 hours a week.



You do the math... make sure they really pay you a salary.
Your pay stub should show 40 hours a week and the equivalent of your "weekly salary" (1/4 of your monthly salary
There should not be a hourly rate on your pay check.

Get all your pay stubs and march into the Labor Court.... your employer has it coming.



Just read that you are a manager... now they are in real trouble. You have an annual salary and it should be min.
twice your states minimum wage times 40 hours a week times 52 weeks = annual salary.



You should run a search on your states Labor Laws - Salary and read up on it  and after that definitely make an appointment with the Labor Court or a good lawyer. They have to pay you back for all the years they cheated you.

<question from>



Denise Robertson
Member since: 21 August 2006
Total points: 88 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



In which areas of life, if any, do women outperform men?



Yahoo! Staff Note: This is the real Denise Robertson, please see the Yahoo! Answers blog for further details:



http://uk.blog.360.yahoo.com/blog-qT1KKP...



</question>



<answer from>



Darran
Member since: 25 September 2006
Total points: 164 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I'd like to get to a point when comparing men and women in this way becomes as unacceptable as saying that you are better or worse at something because of your race.



Parents, teachers and contemparies emphasise certain skills when bringing up girls, and different ones when bringing up boys. I don't think we should see qualities as being exclusively male or female, but that each individual is a blend of different skills and attributes. This male-female polarised view of life is impractical and outdated. And I'm also not sure it was ever entirely true. Working class women always worked while bringing up the kids and minding the house. The idea of a stay at home mum was a pretty middle class one.



I was brought up with many examples of strong, hardworking, intelligent women around me and I learnt to respect the contribution they made to my family, the wider community and to their work. I know families where the woman had to be both provider and carer because of divorce or death - quite common after the last war. But I also know of a family where the father took on the mother's role after his wife died. Despite everyone saying he wouldn't manage he did and was a brilliant dad to two daughters and now a brilliant grandad.



Obviously there are some physical differences, but strength comes in many forms. My wife might not be able to lift as much as me, but I absolutely know that I would not have been able to cope with child birth like she did.



The stresses of modern society, such as the cost of providing a home, mean that more than ever men and women need to work in partnership. And there can be positive side-effects to this: I've had much more opportunity to spend time with my children and watch them grow - unlike my father, to his regret - because my wife works.



I've seen many positive things change about the workplace because of the increase in women in work, and it's hard to imagine going back to how things were ten or fifteen years ago. Women have so much to offer in a business environment, and we lose so many opportunities because we don't take full advantage of their skills, insights and different working styles. I often wonder how long we can go on pretending that 50% of the population should be paid less or given less opportunities than the other 50% based simply on their genitalia.



But I think that things are changing and I hope that by the time my son and daughter are of working age, they will enjoy equal opportunities based on their skills, drive and goals rather than on their sex.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



I am very heartened by these answers. I chose Darran because his feelings most closely mirror my own feeling that, despite physical differences, men and women are the same emotionally and intellectually. Many people said this but Darran's answer pointed us towards a hopeful future.



</asker's comment>

<answer>



by saying new job, i assume you already have a job.  it's actually the best time to look for a new job when you already have a job.  if you don't have a job, well you have no choice.  will you find one?  perhaps.  will you find one that's better for you and relatively soon?  not as likely with the way the economy and unemployment rates are currently.



point is, if you have a job, stay and it's ok to look at the same time.  but just don't quit to look  and don't quit until you get a new job.  never a bad time to just look. how successful you'll be at finding the right job for you, that's the bigger question.



</answer>

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



You don't say where you are.  In the US, in almost all states, employees are what's called employees at will, and can be fired without their having recourse as long as they aren't fired due to a legally prohibited reason like their gender, race, religion or national origin.  The docc should talk to a different lawyer, not to HER attorney.  She is NOT technically correct if she's an employee at will.



</answer>

<question from>



jennifer...
Member since: 25 April 2006
Total points: 2113 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



Help! What do you think of this interview thank you letter?



I had an interview this morning for a promotional marketing position and I'd like to send my thank you letter but I thought I'd better get some second opinions.



What do you guys think of what I've come up with? (see below)
Any suggestions?
Thanks so much!
(I've omitted names and such)



Dear Mr. ______:



I would like to thank you for taking the time to interview me today for the ________________ Manager position.



I appreciate the time that you spent discussing your specific expectations for the ________ Manager position.
I am more convinced than ever that I will fit in beautifully as a member of the team and contribute my skills and talents for the benefit of the _________________ program.



I believe that my credentials make me an ideal candidate for the position.
As I mentioned in my interview with you, I have 11 years experiential marketing experience working with more than 100 different products and clients. These campaigns have ranged from local weekend sampling to multi-million dollar nationwide tours.
Over the past eight years of my career I have successfully trained and managed staffs of more than 50 including managers, brand ambassadors, technicians and talent. Being extremely organized with a high attention to detail has allowed me to thrive under intense work loads while being creative and adaptable in an consistently changing work environment.



I look forward to learning of your decision soon. Please feel free to contact me if I can provide any additional information about my qualifications. Again, Mr. ________, thank you for taking the time to talk with me about this exciting opportunity.



</question>



<answer from>



scobranc...
Member since: 04 October 2007
Total points: 3181 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



It looks pretty good except for a couple of things.  Although they are slightly different, your first two sentences are essentially redundant.  You could either drop one or combine them into one sentence.  I think it's the repetition of "Manager position" at the end of each that is the real problem.



You also have a minor typo in towards the end.  It should be a consistently changing work environment", not "an".



Lastly, I might shy away from using the phrase "fit in beautifully".  It's not bad but something a more along the lines contributing member, outstanding performer, etc.



Overall I'd say it looks very good.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Thanks. I agree about the "beautifully" sentence.



</asker's comment>

<answer>



Go to a restaurant and ask to speak with the manager. Inform the manager that you would like to apply for a position with his or her company. He or she may interview you right on the spot or give you an application to fill out.



1.) Show up like you have it together. Don't look like you just got out of bed and threw something on.



2.) Speak clearly



3.) Show interests



4.) Have a resume ready with references.



All you can do from there is try. Don't get stressed out about it. All they can do is say, "No" Then you move on.



</answer>

MissToy

<question>



What does a legal assistant do mostly?



I'm thinking of going to law school in a couple of years. How could I obtain a job in the law field while being a psychology major? I know that it may be kinda hard to do without being a pre-law major or in a road to law school program. I have no law firm or law experience at all. So I'm trying to understand if I would be able to get an internship or job in a firm and know how to do the job? Or do they train their interns or college employees?



</question>



<answer from>



gettingb...
Member since: 03 February 2008
Total points: 5488 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Getting a job as a legal assistant without law firm experience is almost impossible, IF the firm has you doing complex duties/duties of a paralegal. Legal assistant jobs can vary, depending on the firm. Sometimes, they can be clerical jobs, but often, they require experience and specific skills. In general, you will need to start out as a file clerk, or in another entry-level job. You can get an internship if it is part of a college program. I am in a paralegal program now, and it ends with an internship. That is the only way I know of becoming an intern. I have a BA in a liberal arts field and I am currently trying to find an entry-level job, so I can start building up my law firm experience. I am having a difficult time, even with a high GPA, multiple honors and high-level office experience. I am hoping that once I get more classes completed, I will be able to find something.



You should start checking out entry-level jobs; try Craigslist and your newspapers. There may even be job postings on your campus. There are entry-level jobs out there, you just have to look for them. A lot of them are full-time, so that may conflict with your hours. Just keep your eye open and maybe even send some resumes to local law firms.



</answer>

<answer>



You should definitely register with more than one agency, as they will all have different businesses they work with.

Well, Judges make big bucks, so you could always aspire to that, but it would take you years to reach that goal, plus having to be elected to the spot. <question>



What jobs involve..?



I'm very interested in reading about crimes and watching documentaries on tv about them.

I'm also interested in ancient historical things, especially things like The Battle of Thermopylae between the Greeks and the Persian Empire (most people will know about this from the film 300).

I was wondering, what jobs would involve either of these sorts of things and what qualifications or whatever you would need in order to do them.

Thanks.



</question>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



i can only come up with two:

Archeology
Crime scene invertigator.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



How about a career that involves both crime AND history?

Traditionally, an archaeologist is someone who digs for artifacts and attempts to discover ancient cities to tell the rest of us how previous people and cultures lived in the past. Archaeologists bring history back to life so that the rest of us can enjoy the accomplishments of our ancestors.  This line of work is sometimes referred to as anthropological archeology.

Alternatively, if you're interested in law and solving mysteries, you may want to consider a career in forensic archeology. Forensic archaeologists dig through modern or ancient crime scenes to uncover and inspect evidence, which in turn will help solve the mystery of "whodunit."Forensic archeology professionals play an important role in modern law enforcement as well as solving crimes of the past.  Some forensic archaeologists have even been featured in documentaries concerned with investigating and solving the crimes of ancient history or those committed in more recent times.

What the two fields have in common is the interlacing of clues to create a picture of what happened. Other than that, the two fields are incredibly different. Most people are not even aware of the forensic side of archeology!

To find work as an archaeologist, you will need at least a Bachelor of Arts or a Bachelor of Science degree. Generally, archeology degrees are focused more on the historical or anthropological side than the forensic side. For a career in forensic archeology you may also want to consider a criminal justice program.

With a degree in archeology, you're not destined to spend your days sifting through sand in the hot sun looking for an ancient city. You can work in a college, university, museum, law enforcement agency, or even as a consultant.

To work in a college/university, you'll need a Ph. D and you may be required to "publish or perish," so be sure if you want to go this route, you enjoy researching, analyzing, and reporting your findings in addition to teaching from experience and a textbook. While you may have summers off from classroom work, you can obtain grants to do research in the field.

In a museum, you'll be required to have at least a Master's degree. Here, your life will be similar to that of a professor. You'll be researching, reporting on your findings, and giving lectures to the public. Like to be a little creative? You'll be designing the displays too.

Consultant work will cover everything from field positions that require a B.A. to cultural resources management work that requires a Master's degree. There are also many opportunities to work in government positions.

You may be surprised by the salary connected to careers in archeology. According to JobForge.com, the average salary for an archaeologist as of February 6, 2008 was $64,000. A supervisory archaeologist could make roughly $84,000.  These figures do not necessarily reflect income potential for forensic archaeologists.



Once you determine the field you're most interested in, do a bit more research (dig a little!) to find out what amount you can reasonably expect to earn.

Helping to track down people who "steal history" could be yet another career option.  As part of international law enforcement efforts to stop the theft of stolen or illegally acquired antiquities you could be a guardian of the past, thus preserving history for the future.  INTERPOL and the FBI are two examples of agencies with specialists actively engaged in  hunting real tomb raiders, site thieves, black market antiquity traders, and recovering artifacts.

Other careers that may interest you include historian, anthropologist, crime writer, historical writer, mystery fiction writer, and documentary film maker or producer.



A professional career assessment may provide still more ideas.  Free access to a very insightful career test and the resulting personalized motivational appraisal of personal potential (MAPP) is provided courtesy of JobForge.com. Simply visit http://jobforge.com and click on the career assessment link on the index page or visit http://tinyurl.com/career-test . This career tool will allow you to:

* Find your real motivations, interests, and talents for work
* Identify your ideal careers
* Discover your communication and leadership strengths

Good luck digging up your future!



Source(s):



http://archaeology.about.com/od/forensic...
http://www.jobforge.com/
http://www.assessment.com/MappMembers/We...



</answer>

Tootsie

<answer>



It is important in any letter of resignation, to be dignified and courteous, as well as having a good sense of humour.  Having written many letters of resignation, I consider myself quite an expert.  One tact which might cause a laugh or two, is to have about 5 or 6 in your pocket when you hand one to your line manager.

When he/she says that they cannot accept that, get out another one which they cannot accept.



Working out what they cannot accept within the context of a letter of resignation, is important in understanding the importance of the "letter" of resignation.



It is important because they cannot accept a resignation, unless it is in writing.  So your first step is to offer your resignation verbally.  When they say they need it in writing, bring out the first letter which they cannot accept as it will have a fundamental flaw in it.  (like no signature or pp'd from one of your mates)

Then on the next letter, write 4 or 5 pages, and on the final page say that your resignation is contingent on acceptance of your discussion regarding constructive dismissal.

On the third letter, say that a copy of this letter will be handed to prospective employers as a reference.  Furthermore, you would need it in writing that this was not a formal resignation letter.

In the final letter, write it by hand and make the handwriting completely illegible.



Then after all the letters have been read, and they still will not accept your resignation, throw your hands up in the air and say "Well what about a rise then"



</answer>

<question>



Help with gcse for job?



What gcse's are essential when becoming a personal assistant, and what additional ones are needed. I'm sorry, i have no idea about gcse's, a little help?



</question>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Being a PA is not a clearly defined job such as say a Dentist, Pharmacist etc.  The title can mean anything or nothing. From being a Captain of Industries' right hand to being general Dogs body in some little backstreet firm, or a down trodden serf to some second rate show bizz personality with delusions of grandeur.

The backbone essential subjects for nearly all decent jobs with prospects are pretty much what they were 40 years ago!  English Language.  Mathematics.  A General Science subject. A Language such as French, German or Spanish. Plus, of course, in this day and age, Computer Studies.  You know, all those dreary old subjects that need work!  These days there are far too many airy fairy easy option GCSE subjects available that are of negligible use once  you leave school. Too many pupils are leaving school with high aspirations and a handful of easy option GCSE's then wonder why they cannot get a decent job.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



youll probably need the basic maths english and science, all as high grades as you can get, then anything else is just to prove you have enthusiasm, and all should be high grades really to show general intelligence.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



The only things you really *need* are English and Maths.

You may as well take Computer Studies, but you don't need to because to get a good PA job you'll need to study a formal secretarial course so this should teach you everything you need to know along these lines.

A language could be useful, but again, not a necessity.

Then, I would look to take any subjects that improve your communication skills and research skills, like History.  This is because if and when you eventually get sick of being a PA, one thing that you could perhaps move onto is Operations Management, Project Management, etc, but you'll find making this move difficult if you don't have good communication skills.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Personal Assistant - office work or for a disabled person?



</answer>

<answer>



(1) Do not despair

(2) Consider what *could* be the reasons for you not finding a job:



- You're not qualified enough ---&gt; consider applying for lower level jobs, I know that money is tight for you, but also consider getting a further qualification in your profession

- You're qualified aright, but there are simply no jobs in your field ----&gt; consider changing a field, making a career change

- There's high unemployment level in your area ----&gt; consider applying even to jobs at McDonald's, etc.; consider moving if possible; consider establishing your own business using your skills

- You're not searching well enough: you're looking only in local papers, not on Monster.com, Yahoo! Jobs, Craigslist, http://www.simplyhired.com/ etc.



- Your CV/Cover letter do not look impressive enough - try to work on those skills. This is the last bunch of links attached



(3) Apply more! Someone wrote that he applied here 23 times in six month - this is about the number of applications I have sent in a fortnight  when I was unemployed. Especially that today you can apply online for some positions,
