<answer from>



James N
Member since: 13 August 2008
Total points: 167 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I'm sorry for your struggle, Faith.  It can be really hard getting that foot in the door, particularly when employers ask for resumes to be faxed or emailed and they tell you not to call.  At my workplace, we get dozens of resumes for each available position.

You need to make every effort to have your resume and cover letter stand out.  Your resume is an advertisement for yourself.  It should not read like a chronological list of job descriptions.  If it does, you need to revise it and include things you have achieved in your jobs (e.g. "reduced overhead costs for Department by 15%").  The website below offers several excellent suggestions for doing so.

You should also have more than one resume.  One size does not fit all.  If you are looking for jobs outside your traditional area of experience, you might want to draft a "functional" oriented resume in addition to a traditional chronological one.

Also, your cover letter is the other way to stand out.  It is your opportunity to demonstrate your personality and interest in the position.  I know when you are job hunting, it's easy to get dispirited and send the same canned cover letter to all employers.  Overcome this urge and do your best to make it fresh each time.

Lastly, and most importantly, inquire with friends, relatives, former co-workers, etc. about positions.  Nothing swings the door to an opportunity wider than having a trusted employee vouch for your value and integrity.

I'm keeping my fingers crossed for you.  Good luck!



Source(s):



http://jobstar.org/tools/resume/index.ph...



</answer>

<answer>



If you're interested in becoming a flight attendant, then go with that!  The reason that I say that is because it's the sort of job that people tend to only stick at for a couple of years anyway whilst they're young, so you could do this for a couple of years while you're thinking about what you'd like to study at uni.  I have a friend who is a flight attendant and she similarly thought that her parents would be horrified at the thought of her being a "glorified waitress".  So she went ahead and applied in secret and then only told them when she was selected, and they weren't so bad about it after all!  Remember too that you can make LOADS of money - you pay tax an extremely low rate because you are not classed as being resident in the UK 100% of the time, so even though the basic salary might not sound fantastic, your take-home pay is great.

As the Answerer above has said, most people of your age don't really know what they want to do.  If you are undecided, all you can do is try to take a wide enough range of subjects so that you don't limit your options too early.  I notice that you're not studying any maths or sciences so you're ruling these out.  But you're keeping your options open so that you could go onto almost any Arts degree.  You're probably best to study subjects that interest you and that you're good at and then see where this leads, rather than thinking of a job that you might like to do and then picking subjects to help you get there, as this really will limit your options.



</answer>

<answer from>



manxbike...
Member since: 19 November 2006
Total points: 7174 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



Working hours and holidays are now subject to a raft of legislation aimed at making sure that workers get a reasonable work-life balance that will reduce stress and increase performance. Working hours are restricted to minimum levels although there are some exceptions and loopholes. There are a number of different types of leave as well; annual holiday allowances, compassionate leave, maternity and parental leave to name just a few.



Working Time Directive 
The European Working Time Directive has had a direct impact on many people, particularly those working on production lines and other more traditional factory-based jobs. Generally most workers will now have the right to a non-working period of at least eleven hours each day, a whole 24 hours off every week, a 48 hour working week and four weeks annual leave in each year. There is also a break of at least 20 minutes if the working day is six hours long or more, but the employer is not obliged to pay during the rest period or count it towards the working day.

But the law is very complicated and it's tricky making simple rules. Many of the restrictions on hours are averages so complex time recording and periodical reviews are necessary to ensure compliance. And people can opt out of the working week, either by choice or coercion. Night shift workers also must now have health assessments to make sure that night work is not damaging their health and they are not allowed to opt out.



Peer Pressure
In many white-collar (i.e. office-based) jobs the working hours directives are completely ineffective. As there is no official time keeping in many offices, workers put in long hours if they see their managers and co-workers doing the same, or are pressurised to work for as long as it takes to get a project finished or a deadline met. Many office-based workers will not have union representation either, which makes it difficult to break a culture of commercial and peer pressure that causes this culture of long hours.



Taking Time Off
Many people are lucky enough to have a greater holiday allowance than the norm, currently 24 days each year, for people who work a five day week, and in April 2009 it will go up to 28 days. Part-time workers now receive the same amount of leave as full-timers but pro rata for the hours they work.



Although there are eight Bank Holidays in the UK, employers are not obliged to give them as time off and if they do, they are allowed to count them as part of a holiday allowance. The allowances also depend on whether someone is considered a worker, an employee, or self-employed.



Maternity, Paternity and Parental Leave
Maternity leave has been established for many years now but paternity and parental leave are relatively new on the scene in the UK. Maternity leave is up to 39 weeks on statutory maternity pay although it does vary depending on how long you have been employed. Many employers offer their own scheme, which is likely to be more generous and related to an employee's salary at the time of the pregnancy.



Paternity leave is intended for the non-child carrying partner to be available at the time of the birth and for the first few weeks afterward. Paternal leave can be taken by either parent regardless of their sex and at anytime until the child is 5 years old. Any parent who has been employed for a year or more can take 13 weeks off at any point during those first five years, although it is unpaid. There is more detail about both paternity and parental leave in our Family Commitments article.



Other types of leave, such as compassionate leave, are known in government-speak 'time off for dependants'. There is a statutory right for employees to be given time off, without pay, to deal with emergencies such as a death in the family, an ill child, or anything else concerning a dependant that requires someone to be at home. Employees are allowed 'reasonable' time off, and as with maternity leave, this can be paid, depending on the organisation's policy, if there is one.



Check Contracts
As has been made clear throughout, the government lays down minimum requirements and it is up to the employer to decide whether to stick to those minimums, with regard to both working hours and leave, or to offer more. An employment contract, sometimes with an associated staff handbook, will detail the allowances and improving them is up to the bargaining powers of the employee or a union, if there is a recognised one at the workplace.



Source(s):



http://www.workingrights.co.uk/WorkingHo...



</answer>

this is covered by article 4 of the European worktime directive

Member States shall take the measures necessary to ensure that, where the working day is longer than six hours, every worker is entitled to a rest break, the details of which, including duration and the terms of which it is granted, shall be laid down in collective agreements or agreements between the two sides of industry or, failing that, by national legislation.

<answer>



You are entitled to 20 mins for every six hours worked. The fact that you employer is allowing you to take an hour which can be broken into two 30 min sessions is legal.
However the display screen equipment regulations (H&S Law) state that if you are working with a PC constantly for the 12 hours you are there you should have a workplace assessment, this will take into account your workstation and the type of work you do.
Regulation 4 also states that your employer should be planning your activities so that your use of a display screen is periodically interrupted. Even if this means filing or walking across the office floor this is so you can avert your eyes from the screen and stretch your legs.



The regulatons also state that eye tests must be provided if required.
Look at the HSE website and type in DSE in its search engine, that will give you all the information you need and at work ask for your health and safety representative and request a workplace assessment.



The reason i am giving you this information when your question was about breaks is due to the fact that you should have more breaks if you are sat in front of a screen all day, especially during the busiest period. If your H&S representative is a good one and knows their subject then they should recommend this to your employer.
Good Luck

H&S Advisor ex union rep

<answer>



If you are aged 18 or over, and your working day is at least 6 hours, you have the right to an uninterrupted rest break of at least 20 minutes. Your contract of employment may be more generous than this. There is no law about when this break should happen although government guidelines say that the break should be taken during the day rather than at the beginning or the end. You are entitled to spend your break away from your workstation. Lunch breaks count as rest breaks.



Source(s):



CAB



</answer>

<answer>



Under the provisions of the Working Time Regulations 1998, adult workers whose daily working time is more than six hours are entitled to a rest break of 20 minutes and the break cannot be at the start or end of a shift.

Many people wrongly believe that you are entitled to break after 4 hours of work.  Only young workers (under age 18) whose daily working time is more than four and a half hours are entitled to a rest break of not less than 30 minutes. The break should be uninterrupted "if possible".

There is no requirement imposed by the Regulations for the rest break to be paid. Payment is a contractual matter between the employer and workers.

If your employer makes the change and gives you reasonable notice then there is nothing you can do.  They are complying with the legal requirements and you are not suffering a detriment.



</answer>

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



The traditional Chicken and Egg problem.

That was exactly what I felt when I graduated.

While quite a few jobs are willing to consider people without work experience, you can also try for jobs that require 1-2 years experience in your field. They are likely to be willing to consider someone like you too.



In general, it's not only academic/professional qualifications that matter, but also how you perform in the work place, under the pressures from work which are quite different from pressure from school. So if you have prior work experience, highlight that.

Experience is important because it will show how well you can implement what you learnt in the 'real world'. How you have translated the certification into results which is afterall what all companies are after.

If you have none, then be ready to start from the bottom and prove your mettle. If you are good, you have no need to worry, it is to the advantage of the employer to keep good staff.

Good luck!



</answer>

<question from>



alyssuhh...
Member since: 26 July 2008
Total points: 257 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Does a resume always need a cover page?



I have created a resume for a medical assistant, and I need help on obtaining the position. Does my resume need a cover letter? Where is the best place to print resumes? Can I just turn in my resume to any office, or do I need to wait for an opening posting like online?

Any tips please?
I will choose best answer to whomever helps me most!



</question>



<answer from>



racedowl...
Member since: 10 July 2008
Total points: 1703 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Other - Science



</answer from>



<answer>



A cover page is always nice to do. You can explain why you want the position, and briefly summarize your qualifications.

Unless you have some very unique and hard-to-find skill, if there isn't a position available your resume will be kept "on file," which is a code for it will never again see the light of day. Delivering it in person is always good too, if you can get to see who you will be working for.

Be assertive, the employer does not know you. You'll have to stand out amongst all the others. Make sure your resume is tailored for the specific job, and you know what is required of the position.



Source(s):



I am an employer.



</answer>



<answer from>



CornishB...
Member since: 30 October 2007
Total points: 1471 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



You should include a covering letter with your resume (and with an application form too, in most cases). It acts as an introduction to the employer and you can use it to emphasize the skills you want the employer to especially know about. 
You can send your resume to employers even if there isn't a position available but be prepared to send a lot of them and understand that most will be rejected/ignored.



</answer>



<answer from>



David C
Member since: 27 January 2008
Total points: 889 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Absolutely include a cover letter every time you send out a resume. A lot of recruiters and HR people will not even look at a resume unless it comes with a cover letter. Below I have sited two links. <answer>



IF you need a job then you can not afford to limit your options........
in this economy and slow job market employers can be extremely selective. going into the process openly wondering about how much time off from work you will be allowed or if you will be paid while on leave at some point in time is not the best way to start the process.

IF a job is offered you should have all the information about pay and benefits presented to you so you can make a decision at that time.

it is highly ill-advised at this time to not apply for a job just due to a lack of benefits that fit your needs. after a job is offered you don't have to accept it;  but shouldn't you at least get the offer first?.
at least go to the door and see what is there?

<answer>



In the UK there is a statutory law for maternity leave and pay/allowance. This is quite generous and allows flexibility. I doubt very much if you would find a company that would expand on these terms and conditions. 
Depending on your length of service and your annual pay will determine what you can expect. Acas website or BERR will give you all the information you need.

<answer from>



Paloma Picasso
Member since: 29 April 2006
Total points: 466 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



These days with the bad economy many are out of work, so don't feel so bad. Also, with the child labor laws in effect, 13 years old is still school age and nobody will hire someone so young unless you want to mow the lawn or deliver newspapers. You could start by doing volunteer work. You could check out volunteering in a hospital, nursing home, nutrition center, day care center, and so forth. This will give you a chance to network with others, meet new and interesting people, as well as obtain references for the near future. When I was 15, one of the first jobs I got was a junior counselor at a summer day camp. If you like working with young children, this may be something for you. I don't know where you live, but in New York it is required to obtain working papers for people not of the legal working age. Anyway, you should look into any of these things and remember, you are very young and have plenty of time. As you get older, you will be applicable for new opportunities. Enjoy being young now, because when you are older you will have to work anyway. Good luck.



</answer>

<category>



Business & Finance

</category>



<question from>



iamajeri...
Member since: 20 August 2006
Total points: 608 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Does anyone know the guidelines and timescales for this?



I have been off work for 18 months on long term sick leave. I know its probably dependent on the company but I have heard that after a certain amount of time you can get paid off on medical grounds. I have been paid out on a company pension scheme that pays me part of my salary



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Not sure what your current position is,i.e. are you still employed or not. Assuming you are, generally companies will have two routes to dismissing people on medical grounds. The first is usually for when it is likely someone will work again eventually or could do a different role somewhere else and attracts a sum which will be determined by the company rules. The second is when someone will never work again and this usually allows for pension to be taken early in addition to a sum, but the rules will depend on the pension rules for your particular scheme. All of this will be based on medical evidence normally.



Source(s):



18 Yrs HR Professional



</answer>

</question>

<answer from>



Shona S
Member since: 01 March 2008
Total points: 5249 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



It depends on the crime and how long ago the conviction was. I know someone who was refused as he had been caught driving a car without tax.I've been told that the SIA website has a section on what counts and what doesn't.



</answer>



<answer from>



jackie m
Member since: 10 October 2006
Total points: 17584 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



You need an enhanced disclosure for the SIA licence and they go back for 10 years, anything before 10 years is ok, they obviously don't bother about speeding tickets or petty things like that but if you have served time then it affects you. Go to the SIA website www.SIA.co.uk they have a section that you can fill in and it tells you if you qualify or not. That way you know if its worth paying the £250 to sit the SIA exam which is in Health & Safety & Conflict Management. Hubby had to go through this recently



</answer>

<answer>



The salary for a beginning police officer is excellent.  You can also make more with overtime doing traffic control and security for events.  Many officers in our area make over $100K per year.  As far as "going through the ranks quickly", I wouldn't count on it.

<answer>



The answer is no, as a matter of fact, companies are allowed to check the physical and mental health of their prospective employees.

If their mental health will be a stumbling block in performing their job, then they are not hired.  The same is also true with physical health.



My opinion

Alecs 
***********
Darius, you are correct,  companies never says that an applicant is not hired due to race, gender, sexual preference, etc.  Oftentimes they will only say that the position is now filled.  Sometimes they will not even inform you what happened to your application.



I even encountered a foreign company that never hired homosexuals as the owner views this as a psychological problem!  Even if there is a law, how would you prove that you are being descriminated, specially if they just informed you that the position is filled or closed, and they would further inform you that your application is in their active file for future vacancy.

<answer from>



Chexed
Member since: 13 December 2007
Total points: 205 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



My personal opinion from my assessment of the Human Rights Act is it's NOT illegal... According to the Human Rights Act, Article 14, Prohibition of discrimination, UNLESS they can perform the duties assigned. E.g. I think it would actually be illegal (knowingly and intentionally putting the public in harms way) to hire someone with certain varieties of tourettes as an armed security guard, or a narcoleptic person as an Ambulance driver.
Article 14:"The enjoyment of the rights and freedoms set forth in this Convention shall be secured without discrimination on any ground such as sex, race, colour, language, religion, political or other opinion, national or social origin, association with a national minority, property, birth or other status."
http://www.opsi.gov.uk/ACTS/acts1998/ukp...

That doesn't mean they can't be sued though...
"He was eligible for 26 weeks of disability benefits. But he was fired, instead, in a case that would lead to an $11,000 settlement."
http://www.mscod.state.mn.us/cd/docs/CDd...

If this is serious, you should contact a lawyer and if you have the time read the entire Human Rights Act as well.
http://www.opsi.gov.uk/ACTS/acts1998/ukp...

I'm merely offering my opinion on the representation of this law and only a lawyer should give you his recommendation as far as what to do. Especially considering that the answer may vary depending on which state you live... Another source for clarity (who would probably ask for more specific information from you regarding the mental illness and the job) is your states Human Rights department... You can find your states Human Rights Department by typing your state name at the end of this search:
http://search.yahoo.com/search?p=%22Depa...



</answer>

don't know where you are, but if you are in the UK, this is  my answer...

I went to uni, and I absolutely LOVED it.  I chose a 4 year course that had a "sandwich" year in Berlin (I studied a partial German course),

University to me was one big, long, fun party.  I had the best time, and it is honestly one of the best memories I have of my late teens, early twenties.  The whole rumour of "you have to work really hard" is rubbish.  You work as hard as you have to to get by.  I gained a 2:1 (the second best possible grade).  At the end of it, I worked a few shitty jobs until I got onto a really good career path and accelerated.



My husband on the other hand, didn't go to uni and worked.  He is successful, and didn't need uni or a degree to define his career.  He does occasionally admit that he wishes he had had the experience..

You need to do whatever is right for you.  These days, a degree means nothing (in the UK), and your career will develop adequately without one.  The social side of it however...... it is certainly not something I would swap for the world.  I had a fantastic time.

Good luck, whatever your choice is xxx

<answer>



I vote university!

When you say you "might end up with an ordinary job", I think you need to realise that job prospects are ALWAYS better for graduates than they are for those who have not gone to university.  Perhaps when you're 22 or 23, salaries for a grad vs a non-grad could be comparable, but if you look at those two people ten or fifteen years into the future, the graduate will have progressed considerably whereas the other one won't have.

In fact, I have a problem with the way that you've asked this question.  You say "university vs job/career" but what you mean is "university vs job".  Usually those without a university education end up in dead-end jobs and don't have a real career.

Of course, many people do end up working in fields completely unrelated to their degree, but this doesn't mean that the degree is pointless.  You've still gained soft skills such as communication skills, research skills, etc, which will be useful in any job.

Plus, remember that most people have the best time of their entire lives at uni!



</answer>

Laura M

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



of course you can - you cna work from the age of 13 however the work you can do will be very limited until you reach 16.



The sort of work you can do and the hours you can work will be limited for example you will not be able to work with age restricted products eg alcohol/cigarettes/gambling. You will also not be able to work with dangerous products eg coffee machines.



Check out your local county council website for exact restrictions.

If you are struggling to find work the best thing to do is pop along to your local Connexions centre and ask them to help you write a CV, there are also a lot of websites which can help you with this. A CV is a document which will provide potential employers with information about yourself and what you can bring to their workplace. At your age it is unlikely you will have much work experience but you can make up for this by putting in lots of positives in your personal profile section which is a breif introduction to you.

Hope this helps!!



</answer>

</question from>



<question>



In which areas of life, if any, do women outperform men?



Yahoo! Staff Note: This is the real Denise Robertson, please see the Yahoo! Answers blog for further details: 
http://uk.blog.360.yahoo.com/blog-qT1KKP...



</question>



<answer from>



Darran
Member since: 25 September 2006
Total points: 164 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I'd like to get to a point when comparing men and women in this way becomes as unacceptable as saying that you are better or worse at something because of your race.



Parents, teachers and contemparies emphasise certain skills when bringing up girls, and different ones when bringing up boys. I don't think we should see qualities as being exclusively male or female, but that each individual is a blend of different skills and attributes. This male-female polarised view of life is impractical and outdated. And I'm also not sure it was ever entirely true. Working class women always worked while bringing up the kids and minding the house. The idea of a stay at home mum was a pretty middle class one.



I was brought up with many examples of strong, hardworking, intelligent women around me and I learnt to respect the contribution they made to my family, the wider community and to their work. I know families where the woman had to be both provider and carer because of divorce or death - quite common after the last war. But I also know of a family where the father took on the mother's role after his wife died. Despite everyone saying he wouldn't manage he did and was a brilliant dad to two daughters and now a brilliant grandad.



Obviously there are some physical differences, but strength comes in many forms. My wife might not be able to lift as much as me, but I absolutely know that I would not have been able to cope with child birth like she did.

The stresses of modern society, such as the cost of providing a home, mean that more than ever men and women need to work in partnership. And there can be positive side-effects to this: I've had much more opportunity to spend time with my children and watch them grow - unlike my father, to his regret - because my wife works.

I've seen many positive things change about the workplace because of the increase in women in work, and it's hard to imagine going back to how things were ten or fifteen years ago. Women have so much to offer in a business environment, and we lose so many opportunities because we don't take full advantage of their skills, insights and different working styles. I often wonder how long we can go on pretending that 50% of the population should be paid less or given less opportunities than the other 50% based simply on their genitalia.

But I think that things are changing and I hope that by the time my son and daughter are of working age, they will enjoy equal opportunities based on their skills, drive and goals rather than on their sex.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



I am very heartened by these answers. I chose Darran because his feelings most closely mirror my own feeling that, despite physical differences, men and women are the same emotionally and intellectually. Many people said this but Darran's answer pointed us towards a hopeful future.



</asker's comment>

<answer>



An area of life where women outperform men, is death, or moreover, avoiding it

In the United Kingdom in 2004 women were continuing to live longer than men.

Boys and girls born in 2004 could expect on average to live to 77 and 81 years of age respectively. This contrasts with the turn of the last century when boys born in 1901 could expect to live to 45, and girls to 49. The increase in life expectancy at birth has increased between 1970 and 2004 by eight years for males and six years for females.

http://www.statistics.gov.uk/cci/nugget....



</answer>

<answer>



I think it is not possible to generalize this issue for a number of reasons. Here are a few that I think are relevant: 
1. Despite our sex, we have different abilities and inclinations, and are further complicated by the lives we lead, opportunities we have, and the time we are born in. My mother is the best storyteller I know, but she was born into a repressive society that forced her to become a houseslave. My father loves art but he is an engineer. Naturally, their performances would need to be contrasted with how they would act had they been given the chance to actually choose what they wanted. 
2. Traditional roles are still too strong even in the most progressive societies no matter what people say. Our view of success is very relative. 
3. Economic and social constraints also adversely affect what people can achieve in any given time frame.



I believe we can only take specific individuals at a specific point in time at a specific location to make this kind of statement.



</answer>

<answer from>



jks
Member since: 26 June 2006
Total points: 395 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



There are the obvious choices such as law firm, and public service positions, but there are some not so obvious - military lawyer, research positions, house counsel to non law related corporations, and there are a variety of dual degree options.  There are doctors that are becoming lawyers as well and are then used as expert witnesses in medical cases.  Law Librarianship, FBI, there's lots of options.



To have a law degree of any value, it should come from a school that is approved by the American Bar Association. Most are based at a university.  None of the correspondence or distance ed schools are ABA approved.  Most law schools have recruiters as well as career services offices.  If you are serious, call up a few and see what they offer.



</answer>



<answer from>



Max...
Member since: 05 August 2008
Total points: 399 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



You can work for the unions doing things like negotiations, and policies. You could also work for immigration, Google, MS, and some other companies that need legal advice or advisers. There is quite a bit that you can do without practicing law.  Yes, you really do have to go to university to study law.



</answer>

<question>



Does a 27 year old mature student working in a shop 8 hrs every sat....



.. and more in the school holidays require a contract and terms of employment?  I think it is illegal to be set on without one.  (been there for 6 months)



NO GUESSING PLEASE OFFICIAL SOURCES ONLY THANK YOU

<answer from>



fengirl2
Member since: 02 February 2007
Total points: 18161 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Under UK law, everyone has to have written terms and conditions of employment within 8 weeks of starting. 
In the absence of written terms, the statutory conditions apply, which means you get minimum holidays, sick leave, etc etc.



Source(s):



Employment law trainer



</answer>

<question>



Are barrister and solicitor used interchangeably like our Yank attorney and lawyer?



Is there a difference  in degrees or are they the same profession?



</question>



<answer from>



charlie glue
Member since: 08 December 2006
Total points: 857 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



they are of the same profession but a barrister is more versed in the law than a solicitor.  In other words a solicitor is deemed to be lower than a barrister.  Barristers undergo different training to solicitors and can command more in earnings.

A more detailed comparison can be found here:

http://www.peterjepson.com/law/Alia%20Af...



</answer>

timfoley...

<answer>



No !
In the UK a solicitor takes care of his client whilst the case is in a civil cort or magistrates court. 
If the ase is sent for trial in the Crown courts as they are called the solicitorr then assists the barrister to represent the client in the crown court!

<answer from>



Andrea M
Member since: 14 August 2006
Total points: 260 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



You have done the right thing by asking your employer for time off work, however, they don't have to accept this if there is a business reason for not granting it.

If, however, you are the only person that works in your department, then your employer could be in breach of contract if they refuse to allow you any time off.  You should check whether any other colleagues are treated the same or differently.

You have a number of options if you are not receiving your full holiday entitlement form your employer.  You should try to resolve the matter informally at first, however if this doesn't work, you should raise a formal grievance under the organisation's formal grievance procedure.  If you have trade union representation, they should be able to advise you as well.

There are also organisations that can help to mediate between you and your employer, such as ACAS or the Citizen's Advice Bureaux.  If all else fails, you can look into the option of contacting an employment tribunal, but let's hope it doesn't come to that.



Source(s):



http://www.direct.gov.uk/en/Employment/E...

http://www.direct.gov.uk/en/Employment/R...



</answer>



<answer from>



Chloe M
Member since: 01 August 2008
Total points: 249 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Generally leave (all types, including holiday leave) is at the discretion of your direct Manager, though it can be denied on the basis of 'operational requirements', eg; over christmas or easter period when it may be peak period for some businesses, and they need all hands on deck.

For your situation, it seems simple. You said you have already asked... So what did they say? They must give you an answer straight away (within reason), so you need to press them again for their answer. I understand that they may have no-one to replace you, though this is their issue not yours. At any time you could actually quit altogether, then where would that leave them. It is their responsibility to find appropriate staff coverage, especially for when you (only staffer) WILL (want to) go on leave (holiday, sick, bereavement etc).

Tell them you have already bought your airline tickets and paid for villa in Greece, etc..



Trust that they will be fair, and that they value your contribution to the company to give you deserved time off. Otherwise threaten to quit, then see what they let you do then !!



</answer>

Hippy Chick

<answer>



Firstly, your employer is breaking the law if you don't have a contract.

Secondly, the law doesn't require 28 days annual leave yet - that comes in next April.  At the moment it is minimum 24 days, with no legal requirement for paid bank holidays - subject to you working a 5 day week.
Under working time legislation, you are entitled to this paid annual leave - but this can be at your employers convenience/discretion.  But at some point, you are entitled to the time off (i.e. not paid in lieu).

Speak with the HR manager - and if you don't have one, contact ACAS - they are very good.



</answer>

I have ben told that if they give me any pay rises then I will continue to earn more, which is not fair on them.  My argument is that firstly I was not told about this before I transferred, and secondly that my pay rise (or lack of) is being judged solely on my colleagues salaries rather than my work performance (always excellent reviews).  While I understand where they are coming from, how does a company expect anyone to be happy with this excuse long-term?  Is this really fair?  I am starting to feel under-valued and demotivated, and feel I cannot sustain working for a company that is going to use this excuse every year.

<answer>



I'm not sure what employment law says on this matter, but I think that if an employee is forced to relocate the employer must offer some compensation to offset any costs (such as rehousing or extra transport costs) to the employee.
I work in the public sector and if my post becomes redundant and I am offered a new post at a lower grade then my salary is frozen until the new salary 'catches up'. This may be a condition negotiated by the unions. I would advise you to see a solicitor if the the loss of earnings is enough to warrant it.

<answer>



You are not being undervalued. You are in a particular cicumstance where to be fair to the bulk of the staff they have to be less than generous to you. You say that you were not told that the pay would be lower at HO in the outskirts. That may be so but i find it hard to believe that you were not aware of it. Most people have a pretty fair idea of how the pay structures work throughout their companies.

they are not going to use the 'excuse' [it is NOT an excuse, it is a reason] every year, only until your salary is on parity with the HO rate.

You are only seeing this from your own point of view! I cannot blame you for that, but there is another point of view - the other staff members.

Five years ago, the organisation that i work for when taking over work on sub-contract had to take on 2 of the other parties staff and take over their existing employment contracts on the same terms. These 2 people joined a close knit team of 10 and under 'their' contracts, they started off being paid 20% more than the existing team members and got 6 weeks annual leave instead of 4.  This caused quite a lot of bad feeling amongst the existing staff. The 2 new staff members have had their salary pegged since they joined and have not had an increase in 5 years!  they are now on the same rate as the rest of us. The company cannot do anything about the additional holiday allowance.

Have you considered that had you continued reciving a higher salary then your new colleagues may have become the ones feeling undervalued.

Finally, you mention your excellent reviews, perhaps your colleagues also receive excellent reviews and are every bit as smart as you!

ps Migellito - conditions in the private sector are very different from in the public sector!

<answer>



It's common for the amount of your raise, if any, to depend on where you currently are in the salary range.  Also, ranges are typically lower in areas with a lower cost of living.  You benefitted from an effective "raise" when you transferred to the new area, with a lower cost of living.

Cari
Member since: 01 October 2006

Other - Careers & Employment

<answer>



This is very, very similar to my own situation.

I have not had a payrise since March 2006 because apparently, I'm overpaid compared with my colleagues.  My colleagues have received regular increases to the point where they now earn more or less the same as me.

However, I am not overpaid in the slightest.  Compared with the market rate for my role and industry, I receive a very low salary - my employer has managed to keep its salaries low by employing foreigners who are not familiar with UK salaries and therefore were not able to negotiate a better rate for themselves.

I agree that it is completely unfair to base your salary on someone else's.  Okay, it might be fair enough in a company or industry which uses specific bandings or gradings to award pay, but my employer does not and most people's salaries are arbitrary.

Anyway, I have been arguing this point for a whole year now.  I took it to my Account Director, then to his Manager, and then finally to the CEO.  The Account Director and his Manager were the ones that had been arguing that it was fair.  The CEO agreed that it was extremely unfair, but said "What do you want me to do about it?  It isn't fair if I get involved in negotiating your salary and no-one else's."

Therefore, I know that now my only chance of getting a proper salary increase is to leave my current employer.  I'm still weighing up my options - there are a few good reasons why I would like to stay in the long-term due to prospects for career progression - but at the same time, money is important.

But, I completely agree with you - it does make me feel undervalued and demotivated.  For that reason I have started to look for a new job - just looking, not necessarily with a view to definitely leaving - but I posted my CV on Monster and my Line Manager found it as I work in recruitment.  I was honest with her and told her about the salary situation but although she is my Line Manager, she has no budgetary responsibility and therefore cannot agree an increase herself.  She has now agreed to talk to our Manager, but of course the outcome is just going to be the same as before.

So, I would expect for them to continually use that excuse, and you should consider leaving.  It might not be the right way for you to go at this time as I'm not sure that it is for me, but if you can be clear with yourself on your reasons for staying, then that will be your motivation rather than money.



</answer>

You can wash cars, baby sit, do lawn work, pull weeds, do trash removal. I know a man, and his family who were very down on their luck. This doesn't mean that you can't make money. You can set up your own business like others teens and tweens have over the years, some of them being quite successful. Your local library has a number of books that can help you like "Fast Cash for Kids" by Bonnie & Noel Drew. Ask for it. There are traditional teen jobs like babysitting and yard/house work but if you think about it, you're not limited to that kind of thing. You can sell products and/or provide services that people need. What you do depends on what you can do, what you enjoy doing and what people are willing to pay for. You will make more money working for yourself than for an employer so you have that edge. Discover and use your talents, time and equipment to build a reputable and profitable business. How about the following types of things:

Puppet Shows or Story Time for Younger Kids
Recycling Center for bottles, cans, paper, etc.
Copyright your own design (t-shirts, magnets, bumper stickers)
Furniture Refinishing (turn trash to treasure)
Sell books on specific topics
Write a book or newsletter
Teach people to do things you enjoy (computers?)
Make and Sell Crafts (garden flags, jewelry, ceramics)
Host Yard Sales for busy neighbors
Iron Clothes and/or do laundry
Sell energy light bulbs or programmable thermostats

The list goes on and on but short of selling alcohol, tobacco and firearms you are pretty much free to sell all kinds of products. Get your parents on board to help you. Create a business with integrity and your customers will soon find you.

There've been some pretty profitable businesses at home so yours can be also... Dell Computers, Microsoft, Ebay, Coca Cola, and even Trump Corporation all began small and began at home. Find and need and fill it.



</answer>

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I am a consulting engineer on mechanical and electrical installations in buildings.

My tips are as follows:-

1. Always make sure you put radiators under a window.

2. If you want to be energy efficient, one of the best things you can do is address the efficiency of your lighting - try to use compact fluorescents where possible.

3. Renewable energy - currently, for housing, solar panels on your roof and ground source heating will only pay back their initial investment, including any funding you can get, in 30 - 40 years at best.

4. New houses - the heat loss in winter is actually greatest through bathroom ventilation, if you have a large bathroom or more than one. Install a heat recovery unit.

5. In the near future, the water companies may reduce their guaranteed pressure to your house, meaning, depending on the area, you will have to buy a booster pump to get water to anything higher than ground floor level.

6. Wind turbines on housing DO NOT contibute anything significant in terms of energy.

EDIT: What a great question - I was hoping a KFC employee would tell us just what the secret recipe of 11 herbs and spices really is...

vincentv...

<answer>



There are aspects of public administration that are very similar to corporate governance, yet the social and ethical foundations distinguish it - performing a functions that supports doing works of public good. The MPA can be viewed as similar to an MBA for those wishing to pursue governmental or non-profit careers. An MPA often entails substantial the ethical and sociological aspects not usually found in business schools.

In recent years, public administration theory has occasionally connoted a heavy orientation toward critical theory and postmodern philosophical notions of government, governance, and power, but many public administration scholars support a classic definition of the term which gives weight to constitutionality, service, bureaucratic forms of organization, and hierarchical government.



Source(s):



http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_admi...



</answer>

As it relates to my field (which isn't public administration). . . it's a legitimate academic field for the same reason that business administration is a legitimate academic field.  Basically, an MPA is the equivalent of an MBA for those who are working in the public sector (or who at least spend a lot of time working with the public sector while in the private sector) rather than the private one.

I don't recall ever see PUBLIC ADMINISTRATION available as an undergraduate major.  Majority of Administrator jobs esp supervisory ones in the Government and even private industry require comprehensive background to seeing whole picture of an organization and each one of its components.  There are major haedaches so to speak: OPERATIONS, LOGISTICS, FINANCIAL MGMT, HUMAN RESOURCE etc so in general, I seriously doubt if graduating with a Bachelor's degree in Public Administration is going to OPEN THE RIGHT DOORS to a good job when one graduates from college bec good decisions in real life requires hands-on experience in different work areas in order to understand the whole picture, bec keeping the unit one is assigned efficient and at break even within budget &lt;= is something not possible to be taught in the classroom...

Hope the Above Info Helps!



</answer>

<answer from>



linda_fa...
Member since: 16 July 2008
Total points: 611 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Do your homework.Research the company beforehand so that you can showcase that knowledge during the interview. The internet is a great resource, you can google the company, check business journals for company information, like ranking, sales, mission statement. This will give you a background and later you will be able to ask informed question.

Know where you’re going. Make sure to find out where the office is and how to get there. There are several free sites devoted to directions, Mapquest, Google Maps and Yahoo maps. Know how long the trip will take. Take the name and phone number of the person you’ll be meeting with. Know what the parking situation is, adjust your time accordingly. Save yourself time and unnecessary stress by knowing these things before heading to the interview.

Dress the part.As an Employment Specialist I have experienced this first hand. Two job candidates, different skills, both had criminal background. One gentleman was applying for a warehouse position. He had a suit on. The employers response, “finally someone to interview. The other candidate, more qualified, he wouldn’t take out his facial piercing, no job. Interviews, but no jobs. Your clothing should be neat, pressed, and professional looking. As it can be difficult to know the culture of the office environment beforehand, err on the side of conservative. However, don’t be afraid to inject some personality into your look, and don’t neglect the details. Make sure to have a fresh haircut and clean, manicured nails.

Rehearse beforehand.Prior to your interview, prepare answers to common questions the interviewer is likely to ask, such as What are your strengths and weaknesses? Why do you want to work here? Why should we hire you? and the ever popular Tell me about yourself. You can download interview questions. Conduct a mock interview with a trusted friend as practice. This works best if you can record it. This way you can see what your body language is saying as well. Non-verbal communicates makes up to 80% to 90% of the message being sent.

For more on interview tips visit http://www.bestemploymentresources.com



Source(s):



http:www.bestemploymentresources.com



</answer>



<answer from>



Chris Pascale
Member since: 02 June 2008

<answer>



Go in with a great attitude and a terrific smile.  Wash, condition, and brush your hair.  Wear deodorant and a pair of pants and shirt jus above wht you'd be expected to wear at the job.

When they say, 'tell me about yourself,' do NOT reply with, 'what would you like to know?'

This is where you tell them 2-3 things about yourself.

Mine: I'm a person who works well under pressure and doesn't mind having to prove myself in order to have more responsibility. . . . .



Then I give examples of a time I performed under pressure and another when I proved myself to attain more responsibility.



</answer>

<answer>



Relax...it's that simple. The most important part of an interview is that you and your interviewer "connect". If they feel comfortable with you and you have the skills to do the job then you stand a very good chance.

If you don't connect on a personal level, you stand next to no chance of being offered the job.

Relax, and don't let the nerves get to you.

<answer>



Don't over prepare for the interview by trying to anticipate what questions are going to be asked.  Just be yourself (your professional self), be confident, and answer each question honestly and things will be just fine.  Instead of focusing on the questions they are going to ask, focus on what questions you're going to ask them.  You'll really impress the interviewer by having well thought out questions and showing general knowledge about the company.

Hope this helps.



</answer>

<answer>



look at the job spec which will give you an idea of questions that will be asked

<answer from>



LuckyDuc...
Member since: 26 July 2008

</answer from>



<answer>



Good for you!  My best advice is to learn all that you can about the company. Learn what you can about their products, where's their biggest market, what stores do they sell to,etc.  Admit what you don't know, but give examples of similar things that you were able to learn quickly - for example, if they ask if you've ever  done any bookkeeping and you haven't - be honest, but let them know that you're eager to learn and have some similar experience. "No, I've never done accounts payable, but I'm a very organized record keeper.."



Usually at the end of an interview you're asked, "Do you have any questions?" - that's a perfect time to give a big smile and ask something like,"Well, all of my friends are asking when you're coming out with X design..." or something along those lines. Show a genuine interest in the company, be friendly, and always,always thank the interviewer for their time.



</answer>

Contributing In:

<answer>



Oh, Sara, best wishes and luck to you, how excited you must be!
They might ask you:
Why do you want to work here? ("I like art and making things with my hands") What wage are you looking for? ("Whatever wage you start your entry-level employees at.") What -talents- do you bring to this company? ("I'm honest and conscientious, I care that what I do is of good quality.")
Good questions for you to ask them might be:
Is there opportunity for advancement?
Do you often have overtime, and is it required?
What, in your opinion, would be the hardest part of my job description?
What, in your opinion, is the quality most desired from the person you're looking to hire? (When this is answered, tell them, "I have that quality!")
Take deep breaths and try to be calm, you'll do great.



</answer>

<answer>



the key to a good solid interview is CONFIDENCE.  You should display confidence in what you are doing.  There is no real preparation for an interview ... you should just go in with confidence and honesty.

Don't tell them that you have experience if you dont, you can tell them that you are a "quick learner" and have always had an interest in printing T-Shirts but have never done it.

Do you have reliable transportation to and from work?  That is something you want to bring up if not asked.  (That you DO have transportation, that is.)

When you are done with your interview ... be direct and say "So when do you want me to start work?"  That is confidence!

<question>



Questions about jobs?



why is a letter of application important?

why is an interviwe essential part of the work placment application process?



</question>



<answer from>



Kachia
Member since: 16 July 2008
Total points: 275 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>

</answer>



<answer from>



ferguson...
Member since: 09 May 2007
Total points: 153 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



The interview also gives you the opportunity to see the company and possibly meet some of the employees.  It is as much a chance for you to determine if you want to work there as it is for the employer to decide if you are the right one for the job.



</answer>



<answer from>



Cari
Member since: 01 October 2006
Total points: 18113 (Level 6)



Contributing In:



Other - Careers & Employment



</answer from>



<answer>



A letter of application isn't important.  It can be used to highlight why you are a fit for the job, and why you're applying.  But when my candidates send them to me I never read them - I skip straight to the CV.

An interview is essential because without one, all they would know about you is what's written on your CV.  How can a piece of paper determine whether you're a suitable candidate or not?  They need to get a feeling for your interpersonal skills, how you communicate, etc.  Plus, they also want to ask further information that isn't covered on your CV.  They also want to see you - if it's a job where you need to interact with clients, for example, they need to check that you're presentable.  I would also say that how someone interviews is important - in my experience people who are outgoing, bright, confident and personable will always interview well no matter how crap the interviewer is or what odd-ball questions they're thrown, so you can tell a lot about people by how they perform in interviews.



</answer>



<answer from>



Mike C
Member since: 01 September 2008
Total points: 210 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



The letter of application is often all that you from an applicant therefore it is very important.

An employer will want to know who they are working with and whether you will fit in, hence the interview.



Source(s):



www.employee-problem-page.com



</answer>



<answer from>



merlina
Member since: 29 June 2007
Total points: 2035 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Higher Education (University +)



</answer from>



<answer>



Letters of application tell a potential employer or work experience host a great deal about you.



For example, have you been able to sell yourself well? Is the letter properly and appropriately constructed? Is the spelling and punctuation correct? Does someone look like they have made an effort? Is someone addressing the criteria in the job spec?

Unless all those boxes are ticked the applicant may well fall at the first hurdle.

In every field I've worked in we have had many dozens, sometimes hundreds, of applications for each position - so we need a way to weed out lots of them quickly. Factors like the above enable us to do just that.

Letters are, in some ways, more important than CVs. People often use a standard CV, sometimes one they've had drawn up by a professional CV company, whereas a letter is more likely to be their own work. Even things like addressing the letter to the correct person (whose name is correctly spelled and the right sex) can make the difference between getting to the next stage or not.

The interview is incredibly important. Is the person punctual? Are they appropriately dressed? Again, about 50% of the people I've interviewed have failed on things like that before they've said anything!

Then we will be looking to see if they can communicate effectively in person. For some jobs we will be putting them under pressure to see how they react. Where people claim knowledge of certain fields or processes we'll be asking them about those to make sure they do.

In other words a work placement is no different to getting a 'proper' job.



</answer>

<answer from>



merlina
Member since: 29 June 2007
Total points: 2035 (Level 3)



Contributing In:



Higher Education (University +)



</answer from>



<answer>



It's hard to say what should go on your CV without knowing a little about you and the kind of jobs you're looking for.

Generally, you should emphasise (by putting at the top and giving the most detail) whatever it is that is most likely to attract the employer.

So if you're a school leaver you would prioritise this, followed by any part-time work you've had.

If you've already had a job you would begin with your current or most recent employment details.

There's quite a good guide to writing CVs from Leicester University here: 
http://www.le.ac.uk/ssds/careers/cvs.htm...

The only problem is that it doesn't include any pictures of good CVs. The Work supplement of Saturday's Guardian has a CV clinic every week at the back - that's very good indeed.

Generally you wouldn't put details like those you mention, but if you're very young and never had a job then you could have a field called something like 'positions of responsibility held' and just state that you have looked after your neighbours' animals and babysat regularly

CVs are formal documents and shouldn't be written in the first person (don't use 'I') or sound at all chatty (although your covering letter can be more that way if it's appropriate)

Please ignore the suggestion to mention anything personal (like your sexuality) - that's wholly inappropriate!

Finally, please make sure it's correctly spelled and punctuated. I've discarded more applicants who've told me they have 'GCSE's' than any other single factor!



</answer>

</question from>



<question>



Just starting nursing school-- interested in psychiatric nursing ?



I recently started nursing school in September at a hospital based school.. I never took the Psychiatric nursing part of it yet, but was wondering if anyone is a Psychiatric RN? How do you like it? What does your typical duties consist of? When I tell people I am interested in this field they think I'm crazyy! Can anyone proof them wrong?



</question>



<answer from>



Busy Mommy of 2
Member since: 15 September 2006
Total points: 5529 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Are you interested in working only in a hospital setting? Clinics have Psych departments also, they are usually called Behavioral Health or Mental Health but this is a much safer option to start out if this is what you are interested in specializing in. Plus, you get weekends and holidays off...not to mention a regular day shift of 8-4! I used to be a nurse in Neurology in the clinic and I knew the nurse that ran the Behavioral Health department at the clinic, she was very happy with her job, much less stress than in the hospital, but still dealing with the same aspects.  When working in the clinic you work very closely with the doctors to provide care to the patients. You "room" the patients, getting their vitals and going over the review of systems to get down to the reasons they are their and then the doctor(s) come in make a plan of care and then call you back in to complete any procedure/plan that they have decided upon. Of course, in th eclinic their is a lot of phone work also...calling patients who are in need of medical advice or need their test results. The charting isn't as complicated as it is in a hospital setting because the patient is only in the office for 10-60 minutes, unlike the hospital when they are there for 24 hours or more. There are many more patients to chart on though. It's something to think about, I decided I liked being with my family on weekends, evenings and holidays so I opted for a clinic career. Best of luck to you in nursing school and in your decison to find your "niche".



</answer>

<answer>

<answer>



Orientations are usually done for new employees.  I'd say you have the job.  If they're paying you, you're hired.  If you're still unsure, call and ask or ask after the orientation is finished.

My guess is your interviewer thought they told you, but forgot.  They get frazzled doing interviews too.



</answer>

<answer>



Being bullied at work is an awful experience and any advice given here is easy compared to actually facing the problem.  I must agree however with your Union and you should submit a formal grievance.  This is for two main reasons.



Firstly, although it is the least line of resistance to leave for another job, this would leave you with unresolved issues that may affect you for some time to come.  Mounting a challenge to these people and leaving under your own terms at a later date may be a better course of action in the long term.

Secondly, your Union would be unable to lodge any potential legal challenge on your behalf if the internal processes have not been engaged with.  Even if you do not feel you want to pursue a legal challenge at this point, you should perhaps consider that you may change your mind and that also, future actions by your employer may present you with that opportunity.

These situations can be extremely damaging to our well being.  The principal cause of this and other stresses is the loss of control we feel.  To this end, your challenging the treatment you are receiving is the first step to taking control of the situation and in my experience, people start to get stronger once they have made that first step of submitting a formal complaint.

Get back to your Union and start researching and understanding your employers policies and procedures.  You will be surprised how much of that control you can claw back from them!  Good luck.



Source(s):



Former Trade Union Officer.



</answer>

<answer from>



Poseidon
Member since: 04 August 2007
Total points: 3303 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hello James,

Having worked for the Industrial Tribunals, which deals with unfair dismissals, etc, I feel qualified to answer your question.

My first and most important advice is to contact the Advisory Conciliation & Arbitration Service (ACAS) before doing anything within the company you work for. This is a totally independent government body set up to protect workers and to offer advice & conciliation in workplace issues. The service is free (except the cost of a phone call), confidential and unbiased.

To contact them:

Telephone:  08457 47 47 47

Unfortunately you cannot email ACAS.

The ACAS website is:

http://www.acas.org.uk/index.aspx?articl...

Like sex discrimination, sexual harassment, etc it is illegal to to be harassed or bullied in the workplace.

ACAS will be able to advise you on your rights and the best thing for you to do.

If you are being harassed and bullied by your work colleagues you may have grounds to resign from your employment and make a claim for 'Constructive Dismissal' at an Industrial Tribunal. Constructive dismissal is where someone feels they can no longer work for an employer because of the way they are being treated, Health and Safety issues, etc.

Before doing this though you must follow the complaints procedure within your company and give them the opportunity to resolve the problem.



If you have been working for the company for less than a year, your rights may be less than if you have been there for more than a year.

My other advice is to speak, or write to your immediate superior and make a formal complaint about the way you are being treated. If he/she is involved in the harassment then go straight to the person in overall charge of the branch.



If this fails and if the company has a head office, contact them.

Any evidence you have concerning what is happening in your workplace should be kept and copies, etc provided to those your are making the complaint to. Also any witnesses who may be prepared to give evidence on your behalf should be approached.

As has already been suggested, keep a diary of what is happening.

If your employers decide to, dismiss you because you make a complaint, and you have worked for the company for at least a year, you may also have grounds to claim unfair dismissal via an Industrial Tribunal.

I must repeat that before doing anything, you should contact ACAS first.

Good luck and I hope the problems at work can be resolved.

Poseidon



</answer>



<answer from>



gail
Member since: 08 December 2006
Total points: 1527 (Level 3)



</answer from>

I would imagine that from his present behaviour he is probably having his collar felt by someone above him and is keen to show more than willing. Alienating his own staff will not help him. He probably needs some retraining. The old industry standard for going to a tribunal was two years but quite frankly he is exceeding his remit and would cost the company dearly if he found an UNJUSTIFIED reason to cease your employment after only a few months, and that would include extending your working contractual hours. Look on the www.gov.org. site under employment law - it's a bit long winded but eventually you will find what you need, download it and give him a copy. Head office don't always train their junior management the way they ought to and he may be just as much a victim as you.



Source(s):



A retired director of a plumbers merchants with 35 years personnel experience.



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



Please don't despair. Your contract is everything :)

A contract of employment is a legal agreement between employer and employee. It comes into force when an employee agrees to work for an employer in return for pay; it does not have to be a written contract but can be a verbal agreement. Employers are legally required to put some of the main details of their employees' terms and conditions in writing, including hours, pay and leave. This is called a written statement.

Phone this helpline number on Monday morning and get some expert advice about what you can do about your bully boy employer. (Is he the big cheese, by the way? If not, you may be able to go over his head with your grievance.)

ACAS (Advisory, Conciliation and Arbitration Service)

Helpline -- Tel: 08457 47 47 47 Monday to Friday 8 am to 6 pm

All the best and I hope things are resolved for you soon.



</answer>

<question>



Signing a contract.........?



could someone give me advice please?

i am a trained performer and up until now have only had office jobs but i recently got offered a part in a panto, which is good but its not that well paid and dosent last that long

as it dosent start til november im still on the lookout for further things or better offers.

but they sent a contract which they want signed and returned now, only then do they let you see the script and terms, etc.

what i dont know is if i sign this 'actors agreement' / contract and send it back then in between now and november what if i get offered something better?

ive got to think about what contract is the best job for me, salary wise, length etc so i dont feel its bad to want something better. but obviouisly i want to agree to take it now as i might not get anything else.

if i do get something better, can i not go ahead with it, surely they cant force you?

i have no experience in this area (contracts wise) as i said before i have only had office jobs and i know if you sign up to a job, you can easily resign or leave.

can someone advise, i cant get a lawyer to look over it as i am skint and dont have the time as they want it asap.



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



You need to read the contract word for word and if you don't understand any of it you need to ring the person who sent it to you for a clear clarification.
You only agree to sign it when you understand what is expected from you. If you are offered something better in the meantime then you will need to find out if you will be under a penalty for doing so and what that penalty will be. 
Contracts are tailor made for the role it relates to and I'm sure it will involve penalties for you if you decide at the last minute that you are going to withdraw. If your role plays a senior part and half way through you decide to quit this could cost the company a lot of money so they will obviously do what they can legally from preventing this.
You shouldn't need a lawyer to look over it just make sure you understand everything before you sign it.



</answer>

<question>



I am thinking of being a lawyer?



ok so what types are there.and what does each one do



</question>



<answer from>



neoimper...
Member since: 22 December 2006
Total points: 3127 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Me, I've been a lawyer for over 20 years, and I believe that it is unethical to encourage a young person to go into the practice of law.  Jobs were never plentiful and they are really drying up right now.  Too many lawyers being graduated every year by too many law schools is a good part of the reason.  There are just too many lawyers chasing after too few paying clients, and that's bad for everybody.

Anyway, to answer your question, legal practice generally falls into two categories; criminal and civil.  In criminal practice you can prosecute or defend, and there are two general subcategories of defense.  Those are  represented by public defenders and private practitioners.  Juvenile defense makes up yet another specialized area of criminal practice.

In the civil areas, there is a great deal more to choose from.  There's general civil litigation, business litigation, corporate representation, family litigation (divorces and such), personal injury, debt collection, environmental litigation, civil rights, and appellate litigation.  I'm sure that there are others, but that's what comes to mind just now.

Do yourself a favor and think about doing something more useful.  Even designing computer games will probably make you happier than practicing law will.  The emotional toll that it takes on a person is terrible and it will negatively affect your view of people generally.  Like I said, the job market for lawyers stinks and it is not a very good investment with regard to your future employability.



</answer>

<answer from>



go_dawgs...
Member since: 11 September 2008
Total points: 215 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



If attend a good law school (in the top 50 in the US News Rankings), don't graduate at the bottom of the class, make it a priority to get good work experience during law school (don't wait tables for extra money.  Instead, take unpaid internships and law school clinics that will beef up your resume), and you are willing to put some effort into your job search, you will be able to find a job after graduation.

Yes, it's a competitive field, and there are more law school graduates each year than there are job openings. However, there are something like 200 ABA approved law schools, and also quite a few not accredited by the ABA.  It's the graduates from the no name schools who have a hard time finding a job.

For the answer to your questions (what types of law you can practice and what the job entails), explore this website:
http://www.abanet.org/public.html

Also - please don't listen to Bluecow.  Attorneys are held to high ethical standards.  In order to be admitted to the bar, you have to pass a rigorous background check that includes a credit check, 10 year employment history, criminal history, references, and more.  Then, after bar admission, any unethical practices can be reported to the bar, and the bar investigates and disciplines.  Just like in any profession, there are good people and bad people.

Regarding legal fees, if you go to school for seven years and take a big test, it is reasonable to charge a lot of money.  Plus, there are thousands of attorneys who work for less than teacher's pay in public interest organizations and in government work.

The above poster is clearly not well informed.



</answer>

<answer from>



1x1 pic
Member since: 24 December 2007
Total points: 5946 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



good news: work as a volunteer nurse. experience from these count

bad news: you'll have to pay the hospital for that. learning is very limited because they only let you do vital signs and some routine work: kinda like nursing aides or worse.

suggestion: submit as many application papers to as many hospitals as possible. preferably somewhere you can train or learn and wait for the vacancies. ask the HR if they could just keep your application papers so that if ever vacancies became available, you're already on the list. if you could work in a rural tertiary hospital, then that would be great. if you can't find any, attend seminars and special training (like IV training) to gain an edge.



hospitals in the US (and probably abroad) don't pay much attention to whatever hospital you worked in in the philippines. they, however, pay attention to the experience and training you had. in fact, most hospitals don't even require you to submit your resume and application letter. they have their own application form to be filled out.



</answer>

<answer>



What happens if an employer withdraws a job offer?
=====================================
If the offer's withdrawn before you have a chance to accept, or because you haven't met the conditions (for example, providing a 'satisfactory' reference), you can't take any action, unless it has been withdrawn for reasons of unlawful discrimination.

However, once you've accepted an unconditional offer, and the prospective employer withdraws it, you can claim for compensation for breach of contract.

http://www.direct.gov.uk/en/Employment/S...



</answer>
