<question from>



Legend Killer
Member since: 04 June 2008
Total points: 791 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



What are the job descriptions, salary and requirements for a prosecutor (Law - wise)?



Formal requirements and personal requirements, salary, job description, hours ect. please.



</question>



<answer from>



mallin
Member since: 29 January 2008
Total points: 162 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



To prosecute in the superior courts (anything above the Magistrates) in England & Wales you need to be either a barrister or a solicitor advocate.
To be a barrister you need to join one of the 4 Inns of Court, have either a qualifying law degree (LLB) at 2:1 standard or higher or have a non-qualifying law degree or other degree at 2:1 standard or higher plus a high mark in the Graduate Diploma in Law programme. After joining an Inn of Court you need to complete the Bar Vocational Course and undertake pupillage for a year.
To be a solicitor advocate you need either a qualifying law degree at 2:2 standard or higher or a non-qualifying law degree or other degree at 2:2 standard plus a completion in the Graduate Diploma in Law. After that you need to complete the Legal Practicing Course and complete a training contract with a firm of solicitors. After that you need to specialise in criminal law and undertake a course which will allow you access to the superior courts.
Fledgling barristers tend to earn around £40000 and solicitors around £30000. Highly experienced QCs and top solicitors can earn over £500k and have been reported to earn upto £2 million.
Hours are long, particularly for barristers due to the prep work involved. Time in court is between 9.30 and 4. Rest of the time will be based in chambers/office writing advice, reports or doing more prep work.



Source(s):



AQA AS Law.



</answer>



<answer from>



sharkint...
Member since: 13 June 2006
Total points: 16483 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Salary varies widely depending on where (city,state) you are applying but basically a starting salary borders on pathetic compared to what other lawyers make in the region, the hours are long and the job description involves putting up with a lot of thankless bitchy people and incompetent police.  It requires a law degree and a license.  I don't recommend it, it's a thankless, low paying, dead end, sucky job.



</answer>

<question>



Do I have to file forms if I hire commissioned salesmen?



Hi,

In WA, USA, do I need to file forms with the city or state when I hire commissioned salesmen? Is it legal to hire salespeople with no base salary and have them work commission-only? Would it be legal if it's just part-time and not full-time, or is it illegal for both?

What if the commissioned salespeople are from out of state? Do I need to file forms then?

And lastly, if I don't have an EIN, am I legally allowed to hire commissioned salespeople? What if I get an EIN later? Or do I need to get it first?



</question>



<additional details>



Note: Commissions vary greatly from $500 to $50,000 and up. They can opt to do this part-time while holding a full-time job.



</additional details>



<answer from>



michr
Member since: 03 February 2007
Total points: 46463 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Health Care



Law & Legal



Other - Careers & Employment



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



paying by commission only is only applicable in certain high commission outside sales positions. regardless of how they are paid they must make at least minimum wage for every hour they work and overtime when applicable. 
paying by commission does not change the fact that you are the employer and as such have certain legal responsibilities to the employees as well as regulatory agencies.
you will have to obtain your EIN as well as all other licenses required in the state.



</answer>

<question>



How much do Attorneys at Law make every year?



I'm majoring in Law currently hoping to become an attorney at law.

I'd to know the avg salary a lawyer makes.



</question>



<answer from>



Nash D
Member since: 18 September 2008
Total points: 113 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



As you learn more about the law, you will realize that every answer "depends."  Depends on the jurisdiction, depends on where you went to school, depends on your rank at school, depends on what extra activities you engaged in at school (i.e. moot court, law review, etc.), depends on your outside experience, depends on who you know, etc.

If your image of a lawyer is wealth, your wrong.  most lawyers spend 80 hours a week+ in offices and walk away with $65 grand a year, not much.  If you attend a top-notch school, finish in the top 15% of your class, are a member of moot court and law review, then you can expect to make $130K a year, working 80 hours a week for a large firm.

If you want to go solo, good luck.  They work 2x harder.  One of the hardest obstacles is setting up your own practice.  It costs a lot of money in overhead and retaining new clients is extremely difficult, especially given the competitiveness of law.

You need to specialize, and that takes many years of hard work and experience.  A lot of people go to law school expecting a huge paycheck when they get out.  Truth is, I was making more money as a waiter before I went to law school, working 1/4 of the time, as I am now as a first year graduate.  A nice paycheck can be obtained, but you need to be the best of the best, so-to-speak (Ivy league, top 10%).

Most importantly, don't go into law if all you want to do is to make money.  you will be very disappointed and you will hate the work.  most people go to law school expecting to make money.  When they get out, they either don't make money and hate the work, or they make a liitle money and hate the work.  9 out of 10 lawyers discontiue practicing law within 10 years--something to consider.  Harsh reality, but very much the truth.



</answer>



<asker's comment>



Wow I'd love to know more. If you could somehow email me I'd like to know more.

Thanks for the answer.



</asker's comment>

<answer>



Many are unemployed and make nothing - there are too many lawyers, especially from Tier III and below schools.  At a large firm, a first year associate can make over $125,000.  Most new lawyers make far, far less if they are able to get a job at all.



Source(s):



20+ years practicing law



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 16 October 2007

<answer>



Depends upon the type of law you practice, the size of the firm and most importantly the caliber of your clients.

You can either be stinking rich, obscenely rich or barely surviving on only a few hundred thousand a year in most areas.

For instance at the bottom of the barrel but top of the potential wage scale... how fast can you run down an ambulance?



</answer>

<question>



A job ask me for proof the highest level of education i have  ?



A job is asking me to show proof of the highest level of eduacation i have i dont have a high school diploma but i do have a clerical certfication and a Medical Assisting Diploma and my GED is pending waiting for the results what should i give them ?



</question>



<answer from>



trees750...
Member since: 17 July 2008
Total points: 5050 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Other - Careers & Employment



Other - Diseases



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Bring copies of all of your certificates.  Bring letter a list of your schools with you showing all of your completed certs/degrees and showing the pending GED, so they can verify everything.  They may or may not ask for the educational references.  It's best to be prepared in case they do.

Explain your pending GED and when you expect results.

Sounds like you made the mistake of dropping out of high school.  Much more importantly, you've matured and are getting your education.

You are on the right track and I think you'll do well in the job market.  You've shown maturity, responsibility and that you're a self-starter just by getting your education started.  Good for you!  Best wishes for a bright future.  You deserve it for all of your hard work.



</answer>

<question>



Does anybody know what qualifications are necessary in order to become a paralegal please?



</question>



<answer from>



Chloe R
Member since: 28 July 2008
Total points: 72 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



you need to check the ILEX site



</answer>



<answer from>



gettingb...
Member since: 03 February 2008
Total points: 4612 (Level 4)



Contributing In:



Other - Careers & Employment



</answer from>



<answer>



There really are not any rules when it comes to being a paralegal.  Experience is the absolute most important thing. You are not a paralegal without it, so you have to start in a small firm/work your way up. Many paras are trained on the job and that experience and training is enough to qualify them.

However.....if you have no formal education and lose your job or want to find another one, it will be difficult without some kind of educational background.

Many employers want an ABA-approved school, which you can find at certain community colleges and a few other programs. Online/distance/correspondence programs are not approved and will make you less marketable, so try to avoid those. They also cost a lot more, in most cases.

I am a current paralegal student; I have a BA and I am earning a certificate at a community college.  My school also offers an Associate's degree.  It is approved, which is why I chose it.  I am now trying to find an entry-level law firm job so I can get experience. Having the degree or certificate is not enough-you need at least 2 years of experience for most firms.

If you want to be a paralegal, you should have excellent written and verbal skills, and you need to be able to work with people. You have to be able to work independently and understand that you are working for an attorney, so there are limits on certain things you can do. There are many tasks involved with the job, though, and the people in my class already in law firms like what they do.



</answer>

<question>



Can anyone tell me more about being off long term sick and the consequences? ?



Hi My girlfriend broke her foot 4 months ago and it's still not healed, the doctors keep signing her off and in 4 weeks she has to go back to the hospital to see if it's any better,she has kept her work informed of every move and when she went in on tuesday with another sick line they told her that they would have to get in touch with the big bosses to find out if they could still support her,she was told that they may not be able to hold her position open for much longer. She has been with the company for 5 years now and only works 16 hours a week. On my understanding, I thought they had to keep her position open or at least offer her another one but i don't think they can sack her. Any help with this matter would be greatfully appreiated. Thankyou in advance.



</question>



<answer from>



red
Member since: 19 May 2008
Total points: 5956 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



they go thru a process of trying to help you back to work, if she isnt capable of doing that, they can fire you and you leave with nothing. but it takes  while to go through the process. you can be fired with nothing. they CAN sack her.



Source(s):



experience. seriously. they cant hold your job open forever and its not their problem.



</answer>



<answer from>



Nancy S
Member since: 17 September 2008
Total points: 108 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Family Medical Leave which provides up to 12 weeks of unpaid leave from work  for a serious health condition.  This is a federal law that requires employers to hold an employees job for the time they are out (within 12 weeks).  Because she has been out in excess of 12 weeks, her employer may not be required to bring her back. (Her employer could have a separate leave policy)



Also, because she must have worked at least 1200 hours in the previous year, she may not have worked enough hours to be eligible for FMLA.



</answer>



<answer from>



Mike C
Member since: 01 September 2008
Total points: 230 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



They can dismiss although they should have done the following first:

1] Taken independent medical advice to the effect that she will not be able to return to her job or that it would take an unreasonably long time

2] Fully consulted with your girlfriend

3] Considered any other jobs within their business

4] Been able to show that they can`t keep the job open

It usually comes to a head when she runs out of sick pay.

It will also depend on the size of the business.  An Employment Tribunal will expect a large company to go through more `hoops` than a small one.

Good luck!



Source(s):



www.employee-problem-page.com
20+ years HR Manager FCIPD



</answer>

<answer>



Yes, and I expect if you read your contract or employee handbook it probably states so.

If you actually got sacked because of a mystery customer, it could be worth seeing if you have a case for unfair dismissal - but not saying that you would, without knowing the specifics.  But if it's just a disciplinary, then no problem.

I'm just curious ... what do you think the point of mystery customers are?  Whilst I don't work in a customer-focussed industry, my assumption is that they are there to let the business know how they can improve, and what they should be doing better or differently.  Clearly, no company wants to have rude or unhelpful staff dealing with customers, and if a mystery customer reported you as being a problem, then of course your employer wants to deal with the situation.  That's sort of the point.

<answer>



I used to approach a customer,greet them,and then say something like "If you need any help I'll be over there"and then go and do some paperwork or tidying,always making sure the customer knows where you are.
Another tip which I am sure you're aware of,is to know what you have in stock.I know that can be difficult in a large department,but it will impress people if you can say "yes,we've got those"instead of saying you'll have to go and look.
Also always try and look busy.There's nothing worse than seeing a bunch of sales people standing around chatting and doing nothing.Make it look as though you're tidying and/or cleaning your stock or sales area.You can chat while doing that.Won't only impress your customers,but also your Bosses.
It can be a great career,but it's what you make of it.
You obviously have the right attitude so there's no reason you shouldn't do well.As I say it's up to you.Good luck.

<answer>



Sorry to put such a pessimistic view on things, but in my experience, yes this is wrong.

I too really loved my job and loved the people I worked with - they were like family.  In fact my whole life revolved around work, because when I wasn't working, I would be socialising with work colleagues.  But, things change when it's something that you're not in control of.  Wht happened in my case was that my boss sold the company, and even though I was still doing the same job, I was suddenly working for a company where the people were horrible and it had values and ideologies that I did not agree with.

There are all sorts of things that could happen.  You could lose your job.  You could be injured or something and therefore be unable to work in the same role.  Plus, colleagues move on and you may love the ones you have now, but in a couple of years' time you'll be surrounded by a completely different group of people than you are now.

So, I think it's important to ENJOY your job.  You spend too many hours there to do something that makes you miserable.  But don't LOVE it.  In fact, you sound similar to my situation in that perhaps you don't have much of a life outside of work - I bet you spend all your time socialising with your colleagues too - so my advice to you is that you become unattached from your job.  Detached, whatever.  Enjoy it but don't love it.



</answer>

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Don't be down!  First of all ignore all the idiots on here who are essentially advertising 'get rich, working from home schemes'.  First of all sit down and have a good look at your skills many of them will be transferable to an office environment (e.g. good customer service skills).  Your first step needs to be getting some good basic skills behind you.  Think about going along to your local College and maybe start with a CLAIT computing course or if you think that is too basic ECDL - both these offer a basic standard of computer literacy.  For any office job nowadays good Keyboard skills and knowing your way around a PC are essential.  When looking for office work, perhaps look for a receptionist type role first and then work your way up.  Good Luck, my wife moved from shop to office work a few years ago and now supervises 8 staff!

<question>



Can you get a Saturday job at 14/15?



I am currently 14. I don't get any pocket money and I would like some money so I can go to town or cinema with my friends. I was wondering if i could get a Saturday job in a hairdressers sweeping hair or something like that. I'm not to sure where I stand- I live in the UK, would it be possible?



</question>



<additional details>



You can do work experience at 15 so...?



</additional details>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



yes u can have a job at ur age but ur only allowed to so many hours a week as ur under 16



</answer>



<answer from>



no answerer details



</answer from>



<answer>



In the UK, you are legally allowed to work from the age of 13, but there are restrictions on the type of work you may do and on what hours you work.  These restrictions are generally no longer applicable once you're 16.

Now, just because you're legally allowed to work doesn't mean that you will easily find a job.  I believe that many retailers, for example, have insurance which covers them for staff members who are aged 16 and over.  I think also that some people may view you as too immature - and really, why hire a 14-year-old when you can hire a 16-year-old instead if they're just going to get paid the same.  Plus it may not always be possible for employers to accommodate the hours that you're allowed to work.

I would suggest that if you have a friend or relative who could possibly employ you (e.g. they own a cafe or something) then that would be the easiest way to find work, since they are less likely to be worried that you're immature as they will actually know you.  Plus small businesses will not be worried about the insurance aspect.



</answer>

no answerer details

</answer>

<question>



Can I work in the UK as a physical therapist?



I have graduated from medical school in Novi Sad,Serbia.. as a physical therapist,I went 4 years to school,but I'm currently living in the U.S. and also have their citizenship... How could I work in my field in the UK? Would I be able to get my diploma evaluated if I finish school in the states???  The reason I ask,because I dont like it in the U.S. I love Europe... :)



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



In the UK you may need to do another yr of training, and in the UK they are known as physiotherapists.
The other option is sometimes you could start as a junior, and with initial support within a job you could work up in physiotherapy.
If you have different languages skills you would always be a good choice in the UK.
Look for rotation, or junior posts on www.nhscareers.nhs.uk you can apply for jobs through email, and also they have a phone number on most posts advertised you could always phone that person and ask their advice.
Good luck with your search.



</answer>

<answer>



I used to work in Credit Control, the pay varies. Some places pay 
£9-£10 per hr, some £13, some even up to £20.



Generally, assistant CC's get around 19k
CC's get around 23-25k
Senior CC's can earn 30-35k

Finance Managers (resp. solely for credit control) can earn like 50k.

Depends on business type, sector..etc.



Source(s):



Worked in Sales ledger dept and CC



</answer>

Is a prosecutor a thankless, low paying, dead end, sucky job in the UK?

<answer from>



Cornish Granny

</answer from>



<answer>



In an English court of law you have Barristers, one acts as the defence another will be the Prosecutor. In another case the prosecuting Barrister might be acting for the defendant. I think you've been watching too many American movies. I have never heard of the job as 'Prosecutor'



</answer>



<answer from>



Michael W
Member since: 23 November 2007
Total points: 436 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I doubt that a prosecutor would have a thankless, low paying, dead end, sucky job.

In England and Wales and Northern Ireland (not Scotland), the head of the prosecuting authority is typically known as the Director of Public Prosecutions, and is appointed, not elected. A DPP may be subject to varying degrees of control by the Attorney General, usually by a formal written directive which must be published.

The Crown Prosecution Service normally represent the police for prosecuting people charged. The CPS have their own staff to prosecute but can farm this work out to Solicitors in private practice, who would normally act for defendants, or for more serious trials, the CPS would employ Barristers from various Chambers, some of who would be Queen's Counsel.



You would call these Solicitors and Barrister prosecutors if they were prosecuting for that trial. However, they are not just prosecutors as they may act for defendants in a different trial. So they are eligible to act as a prosecutor or defence in any particular trial.

A prosecutor, who ever it is, would normally command a high salary and the more successful ones would demand their own fee.



</answer>

<answer from>



neverhom...

<answer>



First thing you should do is think about your position and how you have improved since starting.  Have you taken on any new responsibilities?  Are you also doing someone else's role?  What more things do you have on your plate from when you first started.



Come up with a list that you can present to your boss so that you can show an increase in your productivity.  What you are doing is showing him that because you are doing more, you deserve more.



Next, you could ask him about employee reviews.  Tell him you haven't had one since you started and you would like to have a meeting with him.  He'll know what is up.  Basically your boss isn't giving you a raise because you haven't asked for one.  It isn't right, but some people get away with this.



When meeting with him have a number that you want to earn and present it to him.  In fact, you could shoot for even higher than what you want and then he'll come back with another figure and you two can meet somewhere in the middle.  If he values you then he will give you more money so that you stay.



You need to also let him that you do need more money to live.  Tell him you want to keep the job and that is why you are coming to him instead of looking for another job that pays more.  That shows loyalty and also tells him that you want to keep your job.



It isn't easy, but this is the way you have to be when dealing with cheapo bosses.  The good news is they do eventually pay up but you have to initiate things first.



</answer>

<question>



I have a job interview tomorrow, and I don't know how to answer those three questions...?



you know, "tell me about yourself" "why should I hire you"  "why do you want to work here".



It's at  retail place, like Kmart, BiMart, etc.



</question>



<answer from>



Katie
Member since: 10 October 2007
Total points: 8642 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



"Tell me about yourself" - keep it to the traits and attributes you have that will make you successful in the job.  For a retail job I might say something like "I am a people person.  I like to help people and solve problems.  I feel as if I get along with most people I meet and enjoy working in a team oriented enviroment."  If you are in school, mention that and your course of study.  Don't mention anything about your personal life - marriage, kids, whatever  - keep it about your skills



"Why should I hire you" - I give 100% of myself to whatever I am doing.  I am not afraid of hard work and I feel satisfied when I know I do my job well.  I am willing to learn whatever part of the job I need to in order to succeed with this company.



"Why do you want to work here" - This local store has a good reputation in the marketplace and from what I have heard it is employee friendly.  (Only say this if you believe it to be true.)  I have been a customer at KMart for many years and feel comfortable working here and representing this company.



I hope this helps you, even a little bit.  Good luck on the interview.  Dress nicely and professionally, arrive a few minutes early because you might have to fill out an application (but not too early), smile when you meet the person, stand up and shake hands.  Have a few questions ready to ask of them like what are the hours, dress code, what department would I be working for, how long have you been with this company and why do you like working here.  When the interview is over smile and thank the person for his/her time and ask them when they think they will make a decision.



</answer>

<question from>



Danielle S
Member since: 14 May 2008
Total points: 296 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



CA labor law for part-time work?



I work 10-20 hours a week part-time supplement our income at $11.  I'm curious as how I legally should be reporting my time.  For example, this morning I worked for 3 hours, but then had to go back for in the evening for literally 10 min. to do turn down for a guest (I work at a bed & breakfast).  Tomorrow I will be working in the morning for probably 3 hours, then have to return at 3pm to check someone in, then return again at 9pm to check someone in and that only takes 10 min.  My question is, do I report the whole hour?



</question>



</answer from>



<answer>



Your employer should have a policy or rules in place when this happens,  it could be greater than state requires but not less than.  CA Labor law says If an employee is required to report to work a second time in any one workday and is furnished less than two hours of work on the second reporting, he or she must be paid for two hours at his or her regular rate of pay. So even if you go back to work for 10 mins in the same work day you should be paid a min of 2 hours.



Check out this site for more info: http://www.dir.ca.gov/dlse/FAQ_Reporting...



HR Manager



</answer>

<answer from>



Sarah
Member since: 25 September 2008
Total points: 324 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



There are two limbs to the legal test. Firstly, Did you know there was an mistake? Secondly, did you rely on the money?



If, firstly, you did not know there was a mistake, and secondly, you relied on the money, then legally you do not have to pay it back and your employer will not be able to recover the money even if they take you to a tribunal or to court. If they make any deduction from your wages then that would be illegal and you would then be able to recover the deducted money through an employment tribunal.



EDIT: PLEASE DO NOT TAKE ANY NOTICE OF PEOPLE SAYING YOU NEED TO PAY IT BACK... LOOK AT THIS PAGE http://www.ncab.org.uk/Employment%20advi...
UNDER THIS CIRCUMSTANCES YOU DO NOT HAVE TO PAY IT BACK:)



</answer>

<question>



What does it take to become a paralegal?



As far as schooling, training, etc, what is involved? What types sof schools offer this training? After seeing what my husband has gone through the past few years in family court in dealing with his ex and daughter, I've become interested in law myself but do not want to become an attorney.



(I already have a bachelor's degree in a liberal arts field plus a teaching credential if former education has any relevance).



</question>



<answer from>



gettingb...
Member since: 03 February 2008
Total points: 4856 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



First and foremost, experience. No matter where you go to school, you need to have experience, usually about 2 years. I am in a paralegal certificate program; I have a BA and I am attending community college. It is ABA-approved, which is VERY important. I am trying to find an entry-level job now (filing, admin. asst., etc.) because it is extremely rare to find a firm who will start you out as a paralegal. A tiny firm may, but not where I live.



Since you have the BA, you can do what I am doing. Just make sure you go to an approved school. These have to be on-campus, as the ABA will not approve an online school.
The ones in my area that are approved are at the community colleges. My program is 33 credits, which is 10 classes and an internship at the end. It will take me 2 years going at night, pt. Probably the shortest time would be 18 months, because the classes build on each other, but I really think that 2 years is probably the average in my school.



Community colleges, tech schools, and universities offer certificates. Some require a BA, some a BA with a certain GPA and some are strictly paralegal programs that do not involve college credits. My classes are standard college credits that can be used for other programs. My school also offers an Associates degree.



You may want to try getting into a law firm in an entry-level job and then going to school at night, after you see if you like it and also because you need that experience. I wish I had done that this way. I just started the program, so I have some time to build up experience if I can find an entry job.



Good luck to you!



</answer>

Very informative, thank you! Good luck to you too :)



</asker's comment>

<answer>



Hello,



(ANS) No.1 you have my sincerest heart felt sympathy as I can totally relate to your story.



No.2 OK! Lets put this into a wider context here. My dad was a GP a family doctor in Liverpool & when my father completed his training back in the 1950's there was no concept of unemployment & trained doctors expected a job for life in the NHS quite literally.



In the 1950's there existed a much larger manufacturing industry in this country, we used to make ships, cars, aircraft, military hardware, bash metal i.e. make steel & iron and on top of this we used to have old fashioned apprenticeships which often lasted around 5 years for example to become a master printer or master builder etc.



No.3 - In my life time I have seen employment & the world of work turned upside down (during the 1970's particularly). ALL the past notions of employment & job security have gone. Unemployment became a reality & under Margaret Thatcher and the once safe & solid UK manufacturing base was utterly ripped apart under the Tories of the time (people forget this now). In my life time the world has moved from local & national capitalism into global capitalism for better or worse. Global capitalism has changed the entire way we think of work as a result.



No.4 - I read a quote by management Guru Tom Peters about the future of work & the nature of employment. He said a graduate student coming out of university now can expect to have at least 10 or 12 major job changes in his or her working life (40-45years) time in 4 or 5 different skill areas, that people will be forced to have a portfolio of skills ( a bag of skills) & constantly have to retrain & constantly have to re-skill just to stay in paid employment.



No.5 - Do what you love most, try to find work that you can directly relate too NOT just because you have to earn money to pay your bills. Work that touches you inside? work that means something to you NOT just a job because its a means to an end.



No.6 I have come to think that those people like my dad or others I have met along the way. Who have had what we could call a "career" have had a sense of direction & purpose are the lucky one's. What is a career its nothing but a series of jobs or roles for which if looked at over the long term i.e. decades has a flavor or underlying theme. That's what I think a career in the true sense is but NOT everyone is lucky enough to have a career. I don't have any answers myself as I'm in a similar situation too. In other words I DON'T think you or me are alone here, I think there are many people who face the same dilemmas when it comes to work in the current situation, its very confusing.



Ivan

<answer>



First off, don't quit your existing job until you have another lined up.



Well you are asking a few questions but the main one sounds to be "How do I not get bored and stay at a job longer then a year?".



You stated something that was very important. You took your current job just to pay the bills. That is a trap that most people fall into. They just take any job that comes along and don't really think if it is something they want to do. If you really take some time and evaluate what you are looking for in a job and what positions are out there that fit in that criteria you will be a lot happier, do a better job and in the long run probably make more money. But to do that takes a lot more effort then just applying to a ton of jobs and see what one says "yes".



First take some time to really think about what you are looking for and not looking for in a position. The first couple of links I supplied below will help with that.



The second question that you asked is regarding how do I look employable with so many jobs in my past. That is a challenge because on a job search when you are applying for positions you do not want to look like a "job hopper". The best way to combat that is through what is called a "functional" resume. This type of resume focuses on your job skills and not your work history. The third link I sited below will give you and example of a functional resume. You will also want to write a killer cover letter. I gave examples of cover letters below in the fourth link.



Overall you are hitting a point in your life were you want more from a job then just paying bills. To get that takes a lot more effort and a concise, well thought out and professional job search. Finally, the final link I supplied is just to a ton of job search resources that may help.



GOOD LUCK!

<answer from>



scullion
Member since: 20 November 2007
Total points: 3090 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Signing an 'exit summary' can probably do YOU no good.  It could even involve signing away some of your rights, which may be part of why they'd want you to sign it.  If you were in the UK, I'd suspect they were trying to avoid the possibility of your claiming compensation for 'constructive dismissal' which can apply even if you resigned.



You do not need to sign confidentiality undertakings or anything like that because it was implicit in your contract and continues to apply without the need for further documentation.



I suggest you tell them in writing of the correct dates.  Tell them the things you have returned and that you do not believe have anything else belonging to the business.



Ask them to tell you in writing of anything they think you still have.  If they don't reply as suggested then you do not need to communicate with them again.



As you probably appreciate, this career mistake will not look good on a CV and you will need to be careful how you talk about it in future job applications.  Naturally, you cannot expect a glowing reference from this employer though they would put themselves at risk of legal action if they were to give an untrue reference that harmed your job prospects.



Source(s):



Management qualifications and experience; former union officer.



</answer>

<question>



Should I tell my boss about my discomfort in the office?



I have way too many responsibilities in my dental office. I am only an assistant to the doctor and we have two(2) others with my same title.



-When things are misplaced, I'm to blame,
-When a procedure is not set -up or goes wrong, I'm to blame.
-When things aren't ordered, I'm to blame.
-Even when I haven't been in the office in the few days; I'll come back and I'm getting grilled for a case that I didn't even work on.



The grilling is being done by both my manager AND the doctor.



-I'm not the "head assistant" and I haven't been there the longest.



-My boss/ manager continually tells me how valuable I am to our practice and yet I get treated this way.



Should I tell them how I'm feeling "attacked" by them? And if so HOW?



</question>



<answer from>



cb
Member since: 07 August 2008
Total points: 819 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Yes, You really should talk to them. If you let it stew it will just boil over and you will end up saying something or doing something you regret.



This happened to me just a few months ago. I sat down and had a meeting with the "culprits"



I figured if they were still rude and uncaring about it all then I didn't really want to work there anyway.



Make a list of points you want to discuss and go over them with a friend or family member. Don't get over emotional. Just act mature and prepared



It turned out they were totally unaware of their behaviour and were really apologetic and understanding about it. I even got a pay rise!



You have to stand up for yourself, some people are just assholes but most of the time they aren't mind readers.



Hope things work out for you!



</answer>



<asker's comment>



yeah, youre right. any other time i've confronted them about this kind of situation the werent aware of it.



</asker's comment>

<answer>



First let me give you a little detail about the other 3 posts.



Post #1, Affiliate Marketing: a good way to make $$, but there is a learning curve. Figure on researching for hours and hours. But it can be done and you can be successful.



Post #2, MLM: Great way to make money, harder than you think it is, and you are looking at about a years worth of work to make $1000+ a month. But, if you put the time in, it can quickly turn from that $1000 a month into a substantial amount of income.



Post #3, Mystery Shopping. Sorry to the other poster, but you absolutely cannot make $1000 a month mystery shopping, unless you live in a rural area and are working it 40-60 hours a week.



I have done all three of these things in the past, and still do #1&2 (though with different companies/products).



Another thing you can do is build a profitable website on a hobby or skill of yours, but again, profit will not show up for several months.

<question from>



Pooh potter
Member since: 26 May 2008
Total points: 138 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Can an employer make you work right handed if you have worked for them for 20 years in a left handed manner?



I have worked as a postman on a left handed frame all my working time with my employer and now they say I must work right handed .



</question>



<additional details>



I have worked as a postman on a left handed frame all my working time with my employer and now they say I must work right handed .  I am left handed and when I started work there I was told no one can make me work right handed.  It is being done to save the managers extra work.



</additional details>



<answer from>



N S
Member since: 29 August 2007
Total points: 5051 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



It depends if it's a matter of not accommodating a 'disability'. Now, I'm not saying left-handedness is a disability, but it does require accommodations for certain machinery, as most machinery is arguably set up for right handed workers.



If everyone is being forced to change the way they use that machine, there is not much you can do. If the change only affects left-handed workers, you might have a case. If it affects your ability to safely do your job, because a left handed worker, working with their less dominant hand might cause safety problems, then you may have a case.



It really will depend on the reason for the switch. Contact the Labor Board in your state, and ask them what they think.



Good luck.



</answer>



<answer from>



Sharon B
Member since: 07 September 2007
Total points: 840 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



I can't give you the answer, but I would suggest that you see a solicitor, one that gives a free initial consultation and specialises in employment law. Changing your working conditions like this sounds like something tantamount to unfair dismissal. Or maybe your union could help?



</answer>



<answer from>



fletcher...
Member since: 01 October 2008

Post #2, MLM: Great way to make money, harder than you think it is, and you are looking at about a years worth of work to make $1000+ a month. But, if you put the time in, it can quickly turn from that $1000 a month into a substantial amount of income.

<answer from>



UrbanOut...
Member since: 12 January 2008
Total points: 2108 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Sure,



Interviewers are directed to ask every candidate the exact same questions in the exact same manner.



This rarely happens.



Cultural understanding and sensitivity questions are great opportunities to tell interviewers how you’ve helped others or when you’ve shown empathy.. Make up a really short story. Short because interviewers have short attention spans...
You've got 15 or 20 seconds to present your example.



Ability to work under pressure. You must prioritize. The phone rings, and unfortunately, it must be answered immediately. The interviewers want to hear that you’re going to get every task done ‘right now.’ Tell them what they want to hear - in 10-15 seconds.



Prioritizing workload and meeting strict deadlines. Maybe it’s best to stress your strong organizational skills here. How you are perceptive and proactive, and not reactive. You are efficient; so, succinctly tell them what they want to hear.



Good luck.



</answer>

<question>

<answer from>



brittany
Member since: 16 April 2007
Total points: 120 (Level 1)

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Hallmark was my first job while I was in high school. Don't worry about it at all... the interview should be really casual and relaxed, and so long as there is no scheduling problem,  you should assume you'll land the job.



Working at Hallmark was okay, it was fun during the summer as I was young and there was very little responsibility. A major portion of the job, is refilling the cards...new shipments are always coming in.



There are some "corporate" stores, owned by the company, and usually paying more, but the majority of the stores are owned and managed by random people, so your experience will vary greatly depending on what kind of guy you're working for...

<question from>



Marxspar...
Member since: 12 June 2006
Total points: 1294 (Level 3)



</question from>



<question>



What does UK employment law say about making people redundant and then taking on some one to do their job ?



I think there is a rule that says you cant do this, or that there is a time scale you must wait, any help?



</question>



<answer from>



Han
Member since: 30 June 2008
Total points: 3426 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Can't do that. But they could employ somebody to do a similar role, with a different job title.



</answer>



<answer from>



DF
Member since: 25 July 2006
Total points: 7190 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



that would  be illegal, companies get round it by creating a new, similar role with a different job title. you could probably have a good case for tribunal if they did that and often negotiate a better redundancy fee to avoid taking them to one.



</answer>



<answer from>



Steve B
Member since: 19 December 2006
Total points: 65175 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Other - Business & Finance



</answer from>



<answer>



As you may be aware, JOBS are made redundant, not people ..



However if they have multiple Jobs of the same type (eg Project Managers) they can make 1 redundant and then choose which of the employees with this title has to go (the method the use has to be 'fair' i.e. non-discriminatory - in most cases things like your past Performance Valuations are used) ..  .. this may mean some other 'Team' gets split up and that Manager takes over your team ..



However it they eliminate your Job and then recruit a new employee (or promote an existing employee) to do EXACTLY THE SAME job, they are plainly in breach of legislation - your remedy is to claim Unfair Dismissal at the Employment Tribunal (link), however in almost all cases all you get is compensation (it's extremely unlikely you will get your old job back)..



The time sale is, in effect, 6 months (since after that time you can not claim Unfair Dismissal).



Source(s):



http://www.employmenttribunals.gov.uk/cl...



</answer>



<answer from>



Mike C
Member since: 01 September 2008
Total points: 431 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



In the UK redundancy is where the job ceases, diminishes or moves to another location.



If you employer has done this and then replaced you within three months they run the risk of you bringing a claim for unfair dismissal.  You will need one years service to bring the claim.  If you haven`t got one year in you won`t have much re course unless you can demonstrate discrimination etc [for which you don`t need one years service]



Therefore if they waited 3 months, they can get away with it.



Source(s):



www.employee-problem-page.com
20+ years HR Manager FCIPD



</answer>



<answer from>



jackie m
Member since: 10 October 2006
Total points: 18794 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



www.acas.co.uk will answer all your questions but legally they cant take someone on for over a year for your job but the can employ someone to your job but under a different title - if you were a typist they can take someone one and call it receptionist.



</answer>

<question>



Is it illegal for an employer to not want to hire you because of where you live?



So, I had an interview yesterday at a local company and it seemed to be going pretty well, until the end of the interview.The manager interviewing me was going over my application, when he saw that I live in the next town over(About 5 to 10 miles west).He told me that he most likely would not hire me because of where I live.



</question>



<answer from>



Angie
Member since: 09 September 2006
Total points: 10695 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



It is only illegal to not hire for protected reasons, such as religion, sex, race, etc.  Where you live is not protected.  If he doesn't like "Smithtown" and its residents, there's not much you can do about that.



</answer>

Can it state in a reference that you were dismissed?

They knew about my dismissal and were ok with it. When the CAA's HR Dept asked for a reference from my previous employers (the NHS) they stated that I was dismissed for Breach of IT Security Policy!!!!!!! During my disciplinary hearing it was never called that, just Internet Usage Policy. Anyhow, because of the wording of the ref ie security, understandably, the CAA were unable to take me on.

Member since: 02 July 2008

<answer from>



lisab28u...
Member since: 01 April 2006
Total points: 492 (Level 2)

<answer>



You should have received written confirmation of which policy you breached when you were dismissed. Since the CAA were aware of your dismissal and were ok with it (did they offer you the job) then you may have a claim against the CAA. Check your paperwork and if necessary go to see a solicitor for advice (1st half hour is free)



Good luck with trying to make a go of things.

<answer from>



Roy &lt;
Member since: 05 September 2008
Total points: 1167 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



Your former employer's obligation is to provide a true, accurate and fair reference that does not give a misleading impression.



If the reference is not accurate, you could sue them for defamation of character or negligence.



"If the reference contains something which the employee regards as unfair, this could lead to conflict and even litigation. An employee who has been the subject of an inaccurate reference can sue the employer for negligence. This is because the employer had a duty to take reasonable care in the preparation of a reference.



To succeed in such a claim the employee must be able to show that:



the information contained in the reference was misleading;
because of the misleading information, the reference was likely to have a material effect upon the mind of a reasonable recipient of the reference to the detriment of the employee;
the employee suffered loss as a result (for example the withdrawal of a job offer); and
the employer was negligent in providing such a reference."



Source(s):



http://www.out-law.com/page-5851
http://www.elbornes.com/index.php?sectio...



</answer>

<question from>

not amused

<question>



If I email a resume do I need to attach a cover letter too?



Or would I make one Word application with both a cover letter and resume?



</question>



<answer from>



Wonder the Chatty Cat *cries*
Member since: 05 January 2008
Total points: 12070 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Either way you do it (in one doc. or by attaching them individually) it is always best to include a cover letter. :))



However, you should not use the same cover letter each time.  You can use the same basic outline, but each time you apply for a new position, you should tweak the cover letter to each new job you are applying for.



For example, if applying for  a job at the HSUS, you might write about your deep love of animals and cite examples of cat rescues, etc..
But in a cover letter as an Admin. Asst., for example, you would explain why you would make an excellent asset to the office you are applying at...
These are just broad examples. :))



Also, find out the name of the HR Director (or the person who will be interviewing candidates) and mail it to that person's attention.



Example:



Danielle D. Norton, Human Resources Director
Potomac Medical Supply Company
145 Johnstown Road, etc.....



Source(s):



10+ years in HR :)



</answer>

</asker's comment>

I usually have separate documents - one for resume and one for cover letter - so that when I send e-mail attachments they're separate from each other, because the e-mail itself is usually in cover letter format.  However, if you are interested in making it all one document, then go for it, hon.



Just remember, remember, remember to be sure that you ALWAYS have all information correct.  You don't want to send a cover letter that was meant for Company A to Company B.  It looks very careless and unprofessional.



Good luck, hon!

<answer from>



Shash3

<answer>



Many companies do criminal background checks as well as credit reports.  However, they must get your permission to do the credit report.  Most companies want to make sure that you do not have a criminal record or a credit history that would place the company in a compromising position.



You do not have to have perfect credit no do you have to have a blank criminal history to get a job.  Try not to worry and know that this is standard and they are not looking so that they can exclude you, but to ensure their own safety and best interests.

<answer from>



mtwaites
Member since: 02 September 2008
Total points: 4607 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



It depends on what level they are doing this background check. There are some jobs that require that you have a basic background check, and then there are some jobs that require that you have a more detailed check.



Basic Security Check -- this one just basically will tell an employer whether it is a good idea to hire or you, or if there is criminal activity in the present or in the past.



Detailed or Enhanced Check -- this is the one that they can do a whole host of checking such as credit, where you have lived and worked for the past 10 years, you driving record, criminal activity, and what you have done during employment gaps.



</answer>



<answer from>

If you've never been to jail then you'll be fine.

my employer made me do something similar, and i make my prospects for hire go through it as well when i interview at my office.



</answer>



<answer from>



mtwaites
Member since: 02 September 2008
Total points: 4607 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



These type of tests are behavior/scenario like interviews.  They will be giving you a test to see how you think on your feet and how you would be able to different tasks in how they relate to your job as an administrator.



Some examples of scenarios that they may give you to do are:



1) Writing a piece of correspondence regarding a specific issue
2) Creating a spreadsheet or other sort of excel or MS office document
3) Provide a numerous amount of different tasks
4) To organize correctly a couple of senior managers
5) To show how you would organize your day
6) To show a bookkeeping function
7) To explain how you would hire or fire an individual
8) Payroll question
9) Manage a conference or an event
10) A combination of all of these like for instance with multiple choices



This is a small sample of things that you may be required to do as an administrator.



I wish you good luck on the job, and hope that you do well.  Do not get nervous.  This is one of the things that they are testing you for during this interview.



</answer>

<answer>



Do a little research on the company. Learn as much about them as possible, i.e. the history of the company, products offered, customer loyalty, etc... Review the qualifications, skills, duties they posted for the position you are interviewing for. What ever task you are given tomorrow, whether it be organizing a meeting, preparing reports, delegating work to subordinates, what ever it may be, be sure to showcase those qualification and skills required utilizing the wealth of information you learned from researching the company. Perform the tasks as if you are already employed there.

<answer>

If you don't have training in these areas, you should probably get some training in some of these areas if you're wanting to work in these areas.

<answer from>



Jaime D
Member since: 12 October 2008
Total points: 641 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



There's no such thing as a diploma level for being a waiter, room attendant and bartender. Unless you're an educated person with a college degree who has to resort to taking those types of jobs. All of those except for being a chef are unskilled jobs. Chefs actually go to culinary school and have to learn to cook well.



</answer>



<answer from>



Fascist Pork
Member since: 14 November 2007
Total points: 402 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



All of these jobs require quite a bit of skill to be good at, but in terms of general classification:



1.Waiter(diploma level) - Unskilled
2.Bartender(diploma level) - Unskilled (can go to school for this, but still considered unskilled)
3.chef - Skilled or Unskilled depending on the employer (i.e. Chili's = unskilled, Fine dining = Skilled)
4.room attendent(diploma level) - Unskilled



</answer>

<answer from>



mtwaites
Member since: 02 September 2008
Total points: 4607 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



I can appreciate the frustration that you have in this situation.  But when you are hired, you are hired to do what your boss asks of you.  I believe that he thinks you can handle what he gives you, or he wouldn't be giving those tasks to you.  I know that you don't want to work for a low wage, but that is reality.  If you are unhappy with the wage that you're making, then apply for another one of the jobs that he has listed, or look for a company somewhere else that meets your needs.  Bosses are quite smart in the fact that they won't press something on their workers that they cannot do.  Also with what he was mentioning with the Front of House manager, it is possible that he is testing you to see how you would be in that role.  Don't argue with him, just do what he asks, and you might find yourself going up in role or stature within your company. Just because he posted the jobs doesn't mean that he doesn't want you or doesn't want anyone else within the company.  He is just wanting to post the positions in case the tests that he gives you guys don't work out.  I hope that this helps.



</answer>

<answer from>



Georgia K
Member since: 30 October 2008
Total points: 107 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



A cover letter must always accompany your resume and/or application to an employer. When emailing your resume, you may choose to incorporate your cover letter into the email document. If you choose to attach and send the cover letter to be printed, be sure to include a brief introduction in the actual email document as well. Put a specific subject line and a brief message within your email document, to let the recipient know the attached files aren’t viruses.



COVER LETTER DO'S & DON'TS:
DO find out the name and title of the person who makes hiring



decisions and write to her/him directly if at all possible.



DO address the letter to “Dear Sir or Madame” if you absolutely can’t find out the name of the person you are writing to.



DO compose each letter individually for each specific job or



company.



DO be as specific as possible.



DO keep it to one page, especially for entry-level positions.



DO use plain white paper



DO have a date on your letter



DO indicate if you are attaching or enclosing other documents



DO NOT address your letter "To Whom it May Concern".



DO NOT address your letter to “Dear Sir” unless you are 110% sure you are writing to a man.



DO NOT use “Mrs.” or “Miss”, always use “Ms.”



DO NOT write one general letter and send it to several companies



DO NOT begin each sentence with “I”. Describe what you will contribute to the organization, not what you will gain from the position.



DO NOT sign a letter in bright colors such as red, pink or purple.



DO NOT attempt to use a creative format, unless your job is 100% based on creativity.



For more career advice check out CASH (Career Advice & Services Hub) on Facebook



http://www.new.facebook.com/pages/CASH/5...



Become a fan.
Get advice.
Get a job.



Source(s):



http://www.new.facebook.com/pages/CASH/5...
http://www.ns.msu.edu/acrc/quick_guides/...



</answer>

Nicole Y

<question>



What "type"of lawyer do I need?



If my brother-in-law was taken to jail on domestic violence charges that weren't true (really long story short), what lawyer specializes in cases like that? also, he was taken to jail and not read his rights. i need to find a lawyer, but i dont know what "kind" of lawyer i need....please help!



</question>



<answer from>



perfectv...
Member since: 19 June 2007
Total points: 55821 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Video & Online Games



Singles & Dating



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



If the case is to get him out of jail and put an end to his erroneous sentencing, you want a criminal defense attorney.  (The case is the State v. your brother-in-law, and you want an attorney to represent your brother-in-law.)



If the case is to award him monetary damages for being improperly jailed, you want a civil plaintiff's attorney.  (The case would be your brother-in-law v. the police, and you want an attorney to sue the police on behalf of your brother.)



</answer>



<asker's comment>



thank you for clearing that up! your answer helped tremendously!



</asker's comment>

SmartA$$
Member since: 25 May 2007

<answer>



I would try to respond with factual but pointed responses. For example to the question about communism, I would say "I wouldn't know, I've been an American citizen since (year) and I don't keep up on Russian politics"



Sorry you have to endure that. Here's a bit of humor that hopefully cheer you up. I once overheard a woman at a restaurant talking about her recent trip to Canada. I couldn't help but listen in because she was talking louder than anyone should ever talk in a restaurant. At that point I couldn't help but laugh.



Anyway when people ask insensitive questions I would just make it clear that you don't appreciate being stereotyped because of your heritage, and that you are proud to be an American.

Save as much money as possible

<answer>



BPO?  Business Process Outsourcing?



Anyway, it doesn't matter what the position is.



Your approach to the interview should really be the same.  The most important thing to remember is that an interview is a conversation - not a test.  Just relax and try to talk to them as if you were talking to any stranger on the street.  Try to remember that an interview is a two-way street.  You are interviewing the company to determine if you want the job as much as they are deciding if they want to hire you.  Ask the questions you really want to know about the job (this helps remind the interviewer that it is a two-way street).  Be direct and honest.



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 23 October 2008

<answer from>



rascal
Member since: 04 October 2008
Total points: 3190 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hi, well I've never worked in a BPO? but I've been on many an interview over the years.  First, find out as much as you can about the company, as it will prove your interest.  Try to relax (it's difficult), and be honest with the interviewer(s), let them know its your 'first time'.  Make as much eye contact as possible when answering questions.  You will be asked why you want to work there, have an honest answer.  You will probably be asked why they should hire you, so now's the time to 'plug' your qualities and skills.  You may be given hypothetical questions about how you would react to certain situations.  (past experience in any way helps, you may have come across these 'situations' at home or school).  Take your time answering, it's not a race.  Wear something appropriate, but comfortable (you don't want to 'figit' in a tight outfit).  Stay away from 'rambling' when you answer, be concise and stick to the point.  Have a list of references handy (even if they've seen them on your resume), and most important, be yourself.  A good interviewer can spot a fake.  Go into the interview with a positive outlook and a smile.  Good luck!



Source(s):



experience



</answer>

<original file>1098.html</original file>

<current file name>yqa_uk84394.txt</current file name>




<category>



Business & Finance



Careers & Employment



</category>



<question from>



jay
Member since: 29 August 2008
Total points: 47 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



Any RN's? Question for RN's?



im planning on becoming an RN, my question is do you use all the stuff you learn in school once you enter the working world? do you really need to memorize all the biology, anatomy, physiology, etc?



</question>



<answer from>



US_DR_JD
Member since: 23 July 2007
Total points: 33164 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Health Care



San Antonio



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Jay,



You will likely receive different answers from different nurses regarding this.  I know some RNs who are currently working who probably couldn't answer most of your questions regarding anatomy/physiology.  There are many working RNs who probably could not pass the NCLEX-RN exam if they had to take it again. There are others who not only remember what they learned, but also use that information daily in understanding and truly making optimal decisions about the care of the patients assigned to them.



This is not to say that either one does not perform safe care.  An RN in certain areas of health care are rarely faced with anatomy or physiology issues.  An example of this would be psychiatric nurses.  Most of the psychiatric patients have no anatomic or physiologic issues except neurophysiology.  These nurses understand their patients needs, and meet those needs appropriately.  In other areas, RNs are constantly faced with anatomic and physiologic issues.  These are important in understanding the processes and treatments being used.



There are also some people who have a greater abilitiy to retain information, while other learn, and understand, but do not retain for an extended period.  You see this in your current classes, where one student seems to not need to refresh their memory much before finals, while others study for days, yet both make similar grades.



In my personal experiences, I have used most of what I have learned, and require it frequently.  It will depend on the course of your career.



The more you retain, the more well rounded you will be.  But what you need will depend on your requirements.



In nursing school all nurses are taught to take care of children, labor and delivery and geriatric patients.  Yet that is a small percentage of the health care provided in hospitals.  You may have been taught what to do in the delivery room, but if you are working with a pediatric cancer patient, you probably won't need or retain most of it.



Source(s):



RN, Ph.D., CFNP



</answer>

</asker's comment>

<question from>



♥Frijoli...
Member since: 30 July 2006
Total points: 2695 (Level 4)



</question from>



<question>



When creating a resume, is it best to...?



Under each job that you worked, should you use phrases like "My job entailed or Some of my responsibilities or I worked as " ?
Give me an example of what YOU have written.



</question>



<answer from>



stephani...
Member since: 22 July 2008
Total points: 1288 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



I went to a seminar on resume writing and they suggest using as many eye catching words as possible, here are some examples:
"Managed front desk, greeting customers and performing all related clerical duties"
"Delivered new employee orientation sessions"
"Educated patients and family members on care plans"
"Coordinated medical orders"



When employers see strong words like managed, delivered, persuaded, conducted, maintained, it makes them think that you have the know how! Just make sure you give a VERY short explanation of how you managed, etc like i did above!
Hope this helps!



</answer>



<answer from>



Rhubix
Member since: 04 February 2007
Total points: 9763 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



It's best to associate each job with trasnferible skills they help you to develop.



an example would be



Server  xyz restaurant ect....



Working as a server helped me to develop confidence and social skills.I pride myself on quality of service, speed and accuracy.



Try to find things that your old job incorporated that could be applicable to the job your applying to.  A server job may seem unrelated to say an accounting position, but social skills, attention to detail, and quality of work are transferable from one to the other.



Don't include skills that are non transferable or irrelevant to the job your applying to. an accounting firm couldn't care less if you could fold a napkin swan.



Be very to the point and relevant.



</answer>



<answer from>



Jone S
Member since: 31 October 2008
Total points: 137 (Level 1)

<question>



The next step toward becoming an RN...?



I have a Bachelor's Degree in Psychology.  What would be my next step...as far as education/schooling is concerned...toward becoming an RN?



</question>

<question from>



ahh
Member since: 06 September 2008
Total points: 463 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



How is it being a surgical nurse to being a rn nurse?



details of money and working



</question>



<answer from>



Jill
Member since: 05 May 2007
Total points: 63847 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Health Care



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



A surgical nurse usually is a RN. RN is the license you hold, surgical nurse is your specific job title for the area you work in (surgery, obviously).



A surgical RN will make the same amount of money that any other RN working in the hospital would make. You don't make more money based on what department you work in, you make more money based on your years of experience.



A new grad RN would start off making about $40-50k per year, depending on what area of the country you live in.



</answer>

<question>



Continue in nursing or follow my passion? ?



I just graduated from nursing school and passed the boards as a Practical Nurse. Nursing was never my first choice but I fell into it for the money but there are no jobs for LPNs outside of nursing homes or psych hospitals, neither of which I'm interested in. I've always wanted my own business but in the meantime the harsh reality is I need money and stability, two things getting my RN would offer. So finish in nursing or back to business?



</question>



<answer from>



US_DR_JD
Member since: 23 July 2007
Total points: 33242 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Health Care



San Antonio



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Actually, I disagree with the above responders.  There is a shortage of slots in RN programs, and a need for RNs.  But if a person is not interested in working in nursing, most quit the occupation and try another quickly.  Then the tuition and the position in school are wasted.



Also, though you may be a fine nurse technically, and know the information to pass boards, I find that nurses regardless of their level (RN or LPN) who are not interested in the occupation, usually perform minimally in the clinical setting when employed.



You will always do better if you are doing what you enjoy.



EDIT:  As a side note; while my wife is an RN, and I am an NP, we also own a travel agency, so we did both.  There are always options.



Source(s):



RN, Ph.D., CFNP



</answer>

Also is it better to wear my hair down, I have long hair, or just tie it back in to a ponytail?
for the makeup, is mascara and lip gloss enough?



Thanks



</question>

neelhtak...

<answer>



The best thing is to be your self. Tell the truth and answer all questions politely. Give em' a smile every once and a while too.
Hair should be worn whichever way you like as long as it is neat.
Makeup should probably be a 'natural' look so no eye shadow or lipstick/lip gloss. Mascara you could probably get away with.

<answer from>



ktrb
Member since: 20 December 2007
Total points: 21987 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Dress professionally, slightly more than you would for actually working there.  Go easy on the makeup (mascara and lip gloss is fine, but you can wear a little more, like foundation or blush, as long as you don't plaster it on. Use a very light hand).



As for questions, they'll probably ask you about your work habits, how you'd handle difficult customers (a good answer is always "I'd check with my supervisor first") and what you think your biggest fault might be.  Just say "I tend to be a little perfectionist sometimes."  Employers love to hear that.



</answer>



<answer from>



James N
Member since: 14 October 2008
Total points: 241 (Level 1)

<answer>



It does not matter to much about the hair as long as it is tidy, it is not like you are going for a job with the grand hyatt. Most important thing is just to tell the truth and be your self. They will just ask questions relating to your CV to check that what you wrote is true.



They may ask some questions that seem irrelevant, but it is just so they can get an idea of your personality.



Make sure you come across as Professional and approachable, because that is what they are looking for in staff. Retail is easy just smile and look happy all the time.



</answer>



<answer from>



MG
Member since: 16 June 2007

<answer>



http://jobsearch.about.com/od/interviewq...



Not too much makeup, apparently that's a nono on careerbuilder.  Also remember, you always side with the company first.  And if there are any situational questions ie (a co-worker is stealing what would you do?)  A: Tell the manager in confidence.  Retail interviews are all situational,  If there was a disgruntled customer, how would you calm them down ect ect A: assure you will do everything you can to help them out and listen to them with full eye contact to assure them they are being listened to ect ect.  Also they always ask you what's you worst habit.  Always make it a good negative like, "I'm always concerned about time management, so I'm 15 min early to where I need to be." or "I'm a bit of a neat freak, everything has to be orderly and straigh." Good luck!



</answer>

<answer>



Dress and wear your make-up like the women who work there do, that is unless you look even better wearing more or less.



questions don't matter, it's your attitude and honesty in answering them.  Don't say you can do something if you can't.  But when you say you can't do it in a way to give it a positive spin.  such as: I don't know how to ____  but I'm a fast learner.
