<answer from>



trickykp
Member since: 13 October 2008
Total points: 184 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



I would say most of the interview questions will probably be customer service oriented, she may go through some scenarios and ask you how you would handle them. Think of things like that before you go. Think about a rude customer or a customer who wants to return items without a receipt and how you would deal with it. They're also going to ask you about your punctuality and your work ethic. Think of specific examples in your life that show you are punctual and a good employee. Stories about the ways you have resolved problems...etc...are always nice to hear as well. Also make sure that you show interest and excitement in the products you are going to be selling.



As far as clothing and makeup, you want to look put together and fresh. If you're talking about the body shops I know about it's all about looking healthy and vibrant, I wouldn't wear a whole lot of makeup unless you have things you need to hide (acne etc...). Pull your hair back in a low ponytail and make sure it isn't in your eyes. And for clothing, you can't beat black. Wear something comparable to what the other employees wear every day.



Good luck!



</answer>



<answer from>



jjnlove
Member since: 20 December 2007
Total points: 250 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



The important thing is to relax. Make good eye contact and try not to fiddle with you hands. I know it sounds dumb but those little things people notice and they can be distracting.
Some questions they may ask are:
Why do you think you would be good for this job?
Where do you see yourself in 5 years?
What kind of qualities can you bring to the job?
Probably a lot of questions on how you would handle different situations.
Use specific examples from other jobs or volunteer work that illustrate how you have handled a similar situation in the past.
Wear your hair how you feel comfortable. Don't just throw it up in a ponytail, make it look nice in a ponytail if that's how your going to wear it. Makeup is alright, just don't over do it. Try and look natural. You don't want anything distracting the interviewer, you want them to just see all your wonderful qualities and how they could not do the job with out you.
Last thing ask questions about the job? It shows that you are really interested in the position. You don't have to ask a lot unless you really don't understand something about the job.
GOOD LUCK!



</answer>

<question>



Will I get this job? and Is this normal?



I have interviewed twice with a potential employer (hotel) and they stated they are satisfied and seem like they want to hire me. My last interview was with the HR rep who asked me for copies of my social security card, drivers license, and submitted a background check, However she stated that I am not hired yet and I need to interview with one last person, the General Manager. She states she will email me when he can interview me. I am confused as it seems like they are already processing new-hire paperwork but I am not actually hired yet and I am waiting for her email.



</question>



<answer from>



wiseguy
Member since: 24 October 2008
Total points: 187 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



You have not been hired yet.  You may or may not get the job.  What the HR rep is doing is verifying your identity and eligibility to work in this country, which is required by law.



</answer>



<answer from>



Henry
Member since: 28 March 2008
Total points: 3177 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Some companies will do a background check prior to offering you a position, so yes, this is normal.  You also have to interview with the GM before you get a formal offer, but if you've made it this far chances are you're going to get hired.  Be patient.  Sounds like things are going your way so far.



</answer>

<category>



Business & Finance

<question from>



kseb10
Member since: 13 April 2008
Total points: 159 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



The next step toward becoming an RN...?



I have a Bachelor's Degree in Psychology.  What would be my next step...as far as education/schooling is concerned...toward becoming an RN?



</question>



<answer from>



Jill
Member since: 05 May 2007
Total points: 63856 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Health Care



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



Find a program usually referred to as an "accelerated BSN" program. This is designed specifically for people like you, who already hold a bachelor's degree in another field.



You may need a few prerequisite courses, it will depend on what you took for your previous degree and if they transfer correctly or if there is a time limitation on when the courses were taken. But once the pre-reqs are done you will only need about 2 years of nursing courses before you could earn your BSN and be eligible for licensure as an RN.



Source(s):



RN, BSN



</answer>



<answer from>



mtwaites

<answer>



If you are wanting to go onto become to be a Registered Nurse, there maybe some courses that will be comped such as psychology, English etc. as you would have already done most of these academic courses with your degree program.  You may only have to do your clinical and theory courses, and the academics may be comped, depending on when you have taken the degree.  If you have taken the program recently, they will comp them. If it has been more than 5 years then chances are is they may not, but usually they do.

<answer from>

Member since: 06 December 2006

</answer from>



<answer>

</answer>



<answer from>



mtwaites
Member since: 02 September 2008
Total points: 4737 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



Medical transcription is where you have to do a lot of typing up of patient records.  Some of the different types of information that you may be typing from the patient records may include, but not be limited to prescriptions, consultations, laboratory reports, surgical reports, discharge or physical history reports, pathology reports etc.  It all depends on where you would be working for a career. If you're working in a doctor's office, then chances are is it would be just primarily prescription notes or referral forms.  If you work in an emergency, you could be doing a whole bunch of history and physicals, or if you're working on a ward, it depends on the floor that your working on.  If you're working on the surgical floor for example, you will have to do surgical reports, and you may have to do pathology reports etc. as well.  Good luck, and I hope that I answered your question for you.



</answer>

<answer from>



willwork...
Member since: 01 March 2008
Total points: 139 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



From most hiring managers' perspectives, a background check and a credit check are measuring the same thing. The question managers want to know the answer to is, "How are you going to behave and act in the future?" The only way he or she can determine that is based on your past performance, whether that be from a legal standpoint or credit wise.



It has definitely raised some moral questions, but my personal opinion is that it is a useful tool in determining responsibility. If a person is constantly late on making payments, he or she may not show up to work on time. If a person charges way too much on a credit card and only pays the interest, he or she may be irresponsible. Of course, there are other circumstances that could make these cases legitimate, and they should be disclosed to your potential employer. The manager is more likely to hire someone with negative marks on a background report and/or credit rating if the applicant made a good faith effort to explain the situation.



</answer>



<answer from>

Member since: 29 October 2008
Total points: 120 (Level 1)

<question>



What is your opinion about getting job.?



I am a 3rd year student at university in Japan.
a lot of  3rd year student start getting job.



a lot of japanese hope that they want to work from begging to retirement.



I heard people in America change jobs for 2~3 times.
is that true?
and why do they change jobs? they do not want to work until retirement at same company??



</question>



<answer from>



Craig R
Member since: 08 May 2007
Total points: 15203 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I can't answer your question about getting a job in Japan.



In the US, we don't place the same value on staying with one company our entire career as our parents or grandparents did. We tend to work at a place until we get bored or until we've accomplished everything there we want to accomplish. We also find that switching jobs can accelerate our growth in pay. That is, we can get paid more after 10 years by working three jobs than we would if we stayed in one job the entire time.



We also see that many companies do not last very long so the retirement benefits they might offer are worthless. So there's no advantage to staying with one company to build retirement benefits.



Good luck with school and finding a job.



</answer>

<answer from>



vicseo
Member since: 19 December 2007
Total points: 14192 (Level 6)



</answer from>



<answer>



Besides setting all margins to 1", the most important criteria for setting up a professional resume besides relevant text, is "scanability." Here are some helpful tips:



1. Place just below your identification header [your hame, address, phone, email address] any Conditional Warning Statement such as "Confidential Resume,"Do Not Contact Current Employer," etc.
2. Always fill-in an Objectives category [just below the Conditional Warning Statement] and make sure that he Objective will contribute to the profitability of your future employer;
3. Select a mono-type font such as Helvetica, Arial, Courier or Times Roman; do not select any cursive handwriting styles which cannot scanned;
4. Keep font sizes within a range of 10 to 12 pts.;
5. Avoid styling text with a justified alignment, keep it flushed left;
6. Instead of using tabs to set up blocked text entries, generate a table and use the column and row settings accordingly;
7. Do not place an i.d. picture anywhere on the resume, this is a major taboo due to discrimination issues;
8. Do not place any graphic text [saved as .gifs] onto the resume since it may be overlooked during the scanning phase;
9. List at the very end of the resume your interests which should include travel experiences, language skills, social interactions such as golf, team sports, tennis, etc.



In conclusion, the above helpful hints were designed to allow ease of scanning of your resume into PDF which can then be text captured for seach purposes by your potential employer. If the original resume was created in Word, WordPerfect or Mac Appleworks, it can be Saved As a PDF file which then can be saved as an email attachment. Otherwise, you can simply use a scanner and scan a hard copy of the resume and then save as a PDF file.



Failure to conform the resume to appropriate fonts and styles as outlined above will result in rejection of the resume simply due to the inability of the scanning device to properly index relevant resume entries.



Good luck!



</answer>

(IF there is one)

Cubs Girl

<answer>



You would have to go to school for that.  There is a huge waiting list for nursing school call your local community college and ask them.. You can also check for online nursing schools as well.

<answer from>



Jill
Member since: 05 May 2007
Total points: 63837 (Level 7)



Contributing In:



Health Care



Pregnancy



</answer from>



<answer>



It depends on the school where you are looking to get into an RN program. Some require you hold the CNA license (you don't necessarily have to have work experience as one), others do not. You should meet with your school of choice's admissions reps and bring all of your school transcripts. They will see if your courses transfer appropriately and meet their requirements for their pre-reqs. If they match and have been completed in a relatively recent time frame (usually less than 5 years), you won't need to take them over and you can apply directly to the RN program. I am not aware of any state that makes you go through the LPN program first before becoming an RN, but in some places where the wait to get into an RN program is really long, you might be better off becoming an LPN and then taking an LPN to RN bridge program.



Just start calling schools in your area and seeing how many students their nursing programs take each year (and find out how many applicants they get!). Ask if the wait is shorter for a LPN to RN bridge program. Find out if they have wait lists that carry over from year to year. Learn about their entire admissions process and then you'll have a realistic time frame of how long it may take you.



You might have to retake some courses if your classes didn't transfer, but if you really want to be a nurse, you'll suck it up and deal with it and do whatever it takes to get there. Good luck.



</answer>

jim06744

<answer>



assuming you are in U.S, you can go on COBRA for 18 months, whereby you pay 102% of the premium (both the employer and your father's portions so it will be higher) and keep that group coverage. Do that at least as a stopgap. Your father would arrange it thru his employer. Depending on what state you live in you and your earnings you might be eligible for medicaid (fairly low income) or there might be other special programs in that state for those without employer based insurance. You can also buy an individual policy, often from Blue Cross plan in your state or other companies. Call you state insurance department or look at their website.



</answer>

<question>



How can I transition my career from Techie to a Business Analyst? What would I need to know?



Any typical interview questions & answers?
--------------------
- strengths/weaknesses?



- why you?



- etc...



</question>



<answer from>



Jawad helps
Member since: 30 October 2008
Total points: 125 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hi there I have found one site while searching online that will knock you off your feet, you can make more money on it then any other site, out there you can actually make a full time income for this one site and it is free to join and work on. Nothing beats that one i tell you any way. Here is the link. I know they pay as i have been paid over 400$ + an I pod Shuffle From Contest I won, So check  it out, do some offers and make some cash http://quickcarrer.blogspot.com (you can also work there part time or Full Time).



</answer>



<answer from>



cvawt
Member since: 19 December 2006
Total points: 1002 (Level 3)



</answer from>



<answer>



If you are currently in IT, you have a real advantage over many people in the technical aspects of company's systems.  You should focus on having knowledge about income statements, operating expenses, balance sheets, cash flows, and how project NPV and decision point analysis are made.  Business analysts spend a lot of time looking at how parts of the whole are working, so you need to know about the industry you are in and how your company operates compared to competitors.



Business analyst can mean VASTLY different things depending upon the company, so be sure to get a role description and ask a lot of questions about what the position entails and the expectations.



Typical questions are pretty broad like how you have dealt with challenges (give example), where you see yourself in 5 years, describing your past positions and what you like most/least in those roles.



My advice would be to take some finance and accounting classes if you haven't already.



Source(s):



Finance manager with lots of hiring experience for positions like this.



</answer>

Business & Finance

</category>



<question from>



Zeid
Member since: 07 July 2008
Total points: 80 (Level 1)



</question from>



<question>



When applying for a bank teller job.....?



can u go to the bank and get an application OR U HAVE TO DO IT ONLINE??



</question>



<answer from>



Kevin in Texas
Member since: 17 March 2008
Total points: 412 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Most companies have put their recruiting and applications online.



One way or another, your information must be put into the computer system, most would prefer that you do that yourself.



Also, most tracking systems include questions for particular positions that are used to rate your experience and other things (Drugs, jailtime, etc.) to rule you out of a position.



Some companies get hundreds of applications for every job listing they have. They don't need to waste time reading all of them. Most corporate recruiters create a requisition that will screen most applicants out, then they look at the ones that meet a specific percentage and make a determination as to who moves forward. Most of these recruiters spend less than 10 seconds looking at your resume, so you have to have one that catches their eye.



By the way, they will reject you for asking "can u go" versus "can you go" and they will probably pass you by when the see things in all caps.



Source(s):



I've filled out hundreds of online applications.



</answer>

</asker's comment>

How can I start a career in Healthcare?



I have a bachelor's in business, but now I want to go to school for physical therapy.  I have no experience in healthcare whatsoever. What are some things I should do to work towards my new career goal? What are some places that I should try and work while going to school? mistify
Member since: 12 August 2006
Total points: 35829 (Level 7)

Higher Education (University +)

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



I would first look at the APTA website at www.apta.org so you can get an idea of what PT school entails.



Your next step would be to start taking the courses required for entrance into the program to which you hope to apply.  Presumably, you will have to take a lot of the sciences that you did not get as a business major.



As you near the completion of those courses, complete any volunteer hours that are required and take the GRE if required.



A job as a PT technician would fulfill your observation hours..although it does not pay much...but a good experience for someone hoping to become a PT.



Source(s):



I am a PT

<answer from>



lrcarden...
Member since: 26 March 2008
Total points: 226 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



Hi. When you go, just go to the guest service area and let the other target employees know you're there for orientation. They'll either take you or tell you to go to the human resource room. Most likely there will be others there for orientation. You may have to sign a couple of things, read a booklet with the other people there, and then watch a safety video. Then the target employee who is giving you your orientation may give you a little tour of the store and the back room area. After that, you may get a sheet that has your work schedule for about the next 1-2 weeks. During those weeks, you'll be training, for about three days, with another employee who does the work you will do. Most likely, depending on which state you live in, you may only be scheduled for about 4 or 5 days within those 2 weeks. I've been working at Target since June of 08 and this is how my orientation went. The lady who gave our orientation was very nice, and I'm sure you will still get paid for your orientation depending on your state employment laws. I live in Chicago, Illinois so we got paid for ours. Also, like the Targets here in Chicago, employees rarely get 40 hours or more. If we go over 40 hours and have about 48, then they sometimes get a little angry and give us a warning. I'm not sure why they're so strict about this. So, I just wanted to let you know that you may not get the hours you want each week. However, because you got hired around this time of the year, you may get at least 4 days to work each week since Christmas is coming. I haven't been at Target for Christmas yet, but my employees say that it gets very busy and Target needs all the help that it can get. After Christmas, the hours you get will probably drop by about 1 or 2 days. Your boss or ETL (executive team lead) you be the one who will schedule you and post your schedule, along with the other team members schedule, up near the time clock about 3 weeks after your orientation. Hope all of this helps.



</answer>

Help with job interview?



ok so tomorrow i have an interview for a job at old navy and im really bad at interviews so i was wondering if anyone had any tips for me.
also the question that always stumps me is "how will you help our store"



(well thats not exactly the question but its something like that)

<answer from>



HHKIANG
Member since: 03 April 2006
Total points: 316 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



It'll be great if you can wear the clothes of Old Navy's when doing the interview tomorrow. It'll show them you like the brand and pay attention to details. Show your passion about helping people and tell them your working experience in the related fields. If you don't have much  experience, let them know you'll work hard and you're a really fast learner.



To answer your question, you need to pay attention to the store and figure out what you can do to make the store better. For example, if there are clothes scattering around in the wrong places, you can say you love to make sure the customers will have the best shopping experience in this store. Therefore, you will try to keep the store as neat and clean as possible. If you notice not all customers are offered helps, you can say you enjoy talking to people, finding out what they need and helping them. You'll greet all customers you see in the store and make sure they get all helps they need.



Be confident and don't be shy. You'll get the job. Good luck!



Source(s):



personal experience



</answer>

<answer from>

Member since: 02 July 2008

<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



Your experience as a full-time Mom sounds directly applicable to this job.  Find the job requirements for this job--something has probably been put out by the center (a job description, etc.).



Then take each one of their bullet points and think about what you've done as a stay-at home Mom that is similar, then list that.



For example,
if their job description states, "being able to devise and implement multiple projects simultaneously."



You could write, as a mother of x, I have spent the last 6 years juggling mulitiple responsibilities (volunteering at school; arranging for, participating in and transporting multiple kids to multiple activies, all the while ensuring that a safe and comfortable environment was provided for the family, nutritious meals were prepared, and that children's tasks (e.g., learning activities, homework) were completed in a timely and effective manner (assisting as necessary).



Job Title:  Household Manager for a family of XX kids and xx adults, including care of xx animals.



Length:  6 years



Description: point-by-point matching their bullet points in the job description with similar things you've done as a stay-at-home mom as described above.



</answer>

<question from>



Mca8

Total points: 299 (Level 2)



</question from>



<question>



Is it wise or too pushy to call after a few days to check the status of the position after the interviewer has?



gotten a chance to interview a few more people? I was the first one to be interviewed since the posting.  So after an interview, like when they say, 'do you want me to call you, or do you want to call me?" (it's a preschool, and they are more laid back..) i just basically yes, she could call me--if she's interested as she did seem to be, she'll call, right? but now I'm thinking I'll call after all to show interest in a couple days after she's interviewed a couple more people. Pls let me know if it's a good idea.



</question>



<answer from>



Ankhesan amun
Member since: 26 February 2008
Total points: 8224 (Level 5)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



It's tricky.  Most places don't move at lightening speed, especially when hiring.  Calling in, in some places, gets your name dropped into the trash right away.  Harsh and unfair, I know, but I've seen it happen.



I would give it at least 5 business days before you call.  This gives them a bit of time to make a decision and get the word out.  Another option too, is sending a Thank You note.  Nothing wrong with making them remember you, and adding a touch of class to your reputation at the same time.  A side benefit of this, is that it increases your networking potential.  If the people seeing your note, have friends or former co-workers in other day care centers or preschools, they might mention your name and info, if they hear that one of those places is looking for someone.  Many cases, it's not what you know or where you apply, it WHO YOU KNOW.



If you write, call or they call you, and you find out that they have hired someone else, don't let it get to you.  Sometimes places will hire someone who sounded really good in the interview only to find out that they stink on the job...and they go back to their short list and see who they had good feelings about.  You might find yourself being approached at that point.



Good Luck!



</answer>

We sell our products to Asia, North America,South America, Europe,Africa and many places in the world .Due to the Increasing number of clients that we have in the U.S.A, Canada and Europe,we are having difficulty in reaching all of our clients,We supply our goods to all places but our company have problems recieving Payments from USA....

<answer from>



Steve D
Member since: 04 January 2008
Total points: 9947 (Level 5)



Contributing In:



Investing



Personal Finance



Renting & Real Estate



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



While there really is a Keith Ceramic at that url, I highly doubt that this is legit.  Why would Keith Ceramic send you the checks/money orders to cash and then send them the money.  Either the accounts you are collecting on would send the money directly to you, you would cash and send on the 90% or if the money was sent by the debtor to Keith Ceramic, they would cash the checks and send you the 10%.



What will most likely happen is that you cash the money orders/check, send the 90% to whoever is e-mailing you and then watch as the check/MO bounces and you are liable for to the bank for all that cash.



I also note you didn't post the e-mail address of the person sending you the offer.  If the person really works for KCM, the e-mail should be addressed something like Smith_John@kcm.co.uk - if it is a google, yahoo, or similar return e-mail, then you can pretty much figure it is a scam.



Last, re-read the e-mail - lots of grammar mistakes - no legit company would dare allow an official e-mail to go out like that.



</answer>

<question>



What do you think are the skills and behaviors to demonstrate when interacting with a customer?



</question>



<answer from>



Martin
Member since: 01 February 2007
Total points: 946 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



You should be communicative, patient and have good problems solving skills as helping customers = solving their problems.



Cheers,



Kempos



Source(s):



http://www.jobssuperfast.com/



</answer>



<answer from>



PPwallaw...
Member since: 30 October 2008
Total points: 139 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



It all depends on what you are trying to accomplish.  If you are trying to sell someone something then the simple solution is the buddy system, I don't mean a friendly co-worker who will help you along the way.  I mean being the customers friend, asking them fairly personal questions about themselves and there lives, get to know them a bit and make a bit of a connection, this is called 'sweet talking'.  The other kind of service is far more passive.  Hello sir/ma'am.  Can I help you find anything?  How are you?  Simple, small, to the point.  Usually customers are pretty able to do there own thing in most stores most of the time but sometimes people are a little too afraid to reach out to the employee for assistance so asking someone if they need help is usually a huge bonus to them in the realm of customer service (giving them the actual service).
Almost always having a smile on your face and being friendly is generally the rule of thumb here and be sure to avoid negative topics.  Good luck.



Source(s):



Years of retail experience in sales and otherwise.



</answer>

<question>



Tips for a good resume?



What should I put into a resume?

<answer from>



Amanda B
Member since: 04 October 2008
Total points: 155 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



In writing your resume, you must always emphasize your achievements. However, don't overdo it. Write the achievements that you think would compliment the position you are applying for.



Regarding the degree, you can just place their that you are CURRENTLY studying... whatever your course is.



</answer>



<answer from>



Martin
Member since: 01 February 2007
Total points: 946 (Level 2)



</answer from>



<answer>



Write about the things you have done and especially if you achieved something - write about it. But the things should be related to your work. Do not write about something that has no relation to the position you are applying for.

Kempos

Hourly pay ranges for 6.75 -about 8.00 (Team Members- Shift mangers)
And the Salary Management positions range 25k per year - 50k + depending on store and labor/ food costs (assistant mangersGM's)



All the stores in the district are pretty close like all the GM's talk to each other alot so word gets to our district manager fairly easy.



I recently talked to our district manager about advancing to Salaried assistant manger job, expressing that i would like to go to more of the meetings, and employee improvement and training classes.
In his eyes he talks highly of me to the GM's in the district and all the GM's i know speek highly of me as far as work effort, experience and skills.

<answer from>



sphinxte...
Member since: 05 November 2008
Total points: 124 (Level 1)



</answer from>



<answer>



do the math, as a manager making $25000 a year you will be taking a pay cut. salaried managers work 55 hrs a week, and at $25K thats $480 before taxes a week. $8 an hour for 55 hrs is $500 a week before taxes (40 hrs X $8 + 15 hrs X $12 overtime pay). I worked as a manager and NEVER worked the 55 hrs, it was always about 62 hrs plus there was homework. I had no life. here's my tip for you, get a job at a sit down restaurant as a bus person, tell them you would like to learn to be a server. bus people make around $75 a day cash tips plus $3.08 an hour. servers make $3.08 an hour and anywhere from $75 to $300 a day, I average $180 a day and work only 4 days a week! I now have a great life and my managers are working 50 hours a week. non-chain restaurants start managers off at $35,000 a year and work less than chain managers, I have seen 2 servers get promoted to manager this year and they are doing well. my GM makes $95,000 a year and I have another from another location who is 28 years old and is the GM, who started as a backwaiter! get out of fast food, it's a nowhere job, good luck!



</answer>

ﻉ√٥ﺎ

</question from>



<question>



What to expect at my first job interview?



I applied at Mcdonalds, and this will be my first job (if i get the job).



I have no idea what to expect!
What kind of questions will they ask me?
Will I need to bring anything with me to the interview?
What do I wear?



Just anything.. any tips on good ways to present myself. Im really nervous!



</question>



<answer from>



jobbend
Member since: 23 March 2008
Total points: 2819 (Level 4)



</answer from>



<answer>



<evaluation>Best Answer - Chosen by Asker</evaluation>



You want first to be professional, friendly and attentive.  Ways to show that are dress and groom yourself so they can SEE you care about yourself.  If you have references from teachers, clergy, volunteer jobs, bring them.  It just shows you care about work.



You are going to be asked questions about the job you applied for, or that is available.  They are going to want to know about how you are going to get to work, anything that will keep you from performing the tasks of the job, why you want to work there, and when you will be available.



Good luck!



</answer>
